description:
My sister and I came here on a Monday for lunch--the place is pretty tasty! You just tell the counter what udon you want (there are 5 choices), and from then, you can choose different types of tempura if you'd like. There was plenty of open seating for us also, and staff was super nice. 

What we got:
1) cold udon --this was really refreshing and good, even on a colder day. I don't think I have one bad thing to say about this bowl.
2) creamy kabocha chicken udon--creamy, thick broth that gets you full quick. I enjoyed this bowl a lot too!
3) tempura broccoli and pumpkin: the broccoli comes on a kebab, with about 3-4 pieces on it. I enjoyed it but which it was a little crispier/airy. Same goes for the pumpkin.

Overall, I think this is a solid place to go to if you're craving udon--The noodles were nice and chewy, and the portion definitely got my sister and I full. I'd come back again!
author: Shannon N.

description:
Big and spacious, with big tables to share with your group or others, nice lights, and overall good feel.

This is an udon (thick noodle) restaurant where you go to the counter, choose what you want to eat, and put it on a tray, and pay for it. Theres a yelp coupon that gets you a free tempura! 

We ordered curry udon for $13.50+tax and the beef bowl for $14.50 (i think). We also got free shrimp tempura and potato croquette. The udon was delicious, and the curry was good; loved the pickled daikon too. The rice bowl was also great, although the beef was a bit too thick for Japanese gyudon.

All in all, we liked everything we ate but it wasnt mind blowing (its supposed to be comfort food, after all). The main con is that the price seems a bit high, but to be fair the amount and the quality are good. Would come back, but not right away.
author: Mimi Y.

description:
Great quality of food, very efficient, clean and wanna make you go back again. 

Kagawa-Ya is not another chain restaurant for lunch in The Mid Market. Their daily freshly made noodles can't be compared to anywhere else in San Francisco. Some unique and some authentic udon soups are made for each of your favorite flavors. Kagawa-Ya brings me some comfort food tastes like I used to had in Japan. As I've eaten at Kagawa-Ya several times, I can tell that the owner/chef wants to provider good quality of udon for everyone in San Francisco.
author: Akemi M.

description:
3.5 rounding down

Beef Curry Udon $13 ~ friend said it tasted like the package curry and the beef was actually beef stew - the whole meal looked unappealing

Niku Udon $14 ~ there was so much beef in here that over time it became too much but I was left full so that's always a plus, flavor was good and noodles were not as soft as I'd like but no biggie, was also happy I could ask for no white onion

The add-ons: 
- crispy chicken $2 ~ and that was advertised as "limited time"
- potato curry croquette $1.50 ~ this was the best of the 3 but I could've lived without it
- shrimp tempera $1.50 ~ this was most disappointing because (see photo) the tempera I got chosen was the largest on the tray that was available 

$35 for everything, I was a little disappointed so I don't recommend (unless you're trying to complete your Yelp list like me lol) 

for more bang for your buck + add-on free toppings too (cilantro, green onion, tempura crumbs) visit Marugame Udon instead
author: Yeanne L.

description:
Long pending review. Loved that they have a completely vegetarian option which can easily be made vegan by excluding the cheese. 

The broth is tomato based and was very rich in flavors and I loved it. They have a pretty spacious restaurant and as far as I can tell the service is quick (I had ordered ahead so there was no wait for me). It is a self service kind of place. Hope they come up with more vegetarian options , but even the 1 they already have is good.
author: Umang D.

description:
I'm normally not an udon person, but this place was amazing! I got the #7 (zhajiang udon) and my sister got the #5 (creamy kabocha w/chicken udon). Zhajiangmian is one of my favorite dishes and this zhajiang udon did not disappoint! The noodles were super chewy and the sauce was really good, albeit a bit salty, but the pickled radish was a nice touch that balanced it out. I tried my the broth of #5 and it tasted a lot like clam chowder which I actually enjoyed.

Really liked the chill vibe and the high ceilings of the interior. It's not in the safest area on Market St though so I would try to go for lunch.
author: Alice C.

description: Finally got to try this place! I love Maragume Udon and I would say this place is quite similar. Cafeteria style where you can choose your udon and help yourself to tempura, spam masubis, etc. I ordered the Kitsune udon with tempura on the side. Delicious and very filling!
author: Brenna L.

description:
Finally tried Kagawa- Ya near the Civic Center/Van Ness area. They make fresh sanuki udon daily--look at these long strands! 

I got the kitsune udon, which was pleasant, though I would have liked a little more flavor in the broth and a bit more chew to my udon. Other Yelp reviews mentioned the noodles being chewy, so I'm hoping it was just a little over that visit. I would definitely try it again.

You can get a free piece of tempura with a Yelp check-in, so I opted for an ebi/shrimp. Pretty decent, and there's hot tempura sauce near the shichimi togarashi and other condiments.

Seating is cafeteria style, but there are plenty of tables and it was clean.

All in all, it's a quick, enjoyable lunch, and well-priced for San Francisco.
author: Lydia C.

description:
While I was on a walk recently, I decided to give Kagawa-Ya a try. During dinner time on a weekday, there wasn't a wait so we managed to go straight in to order. The menu was very straight-forward. 7 udon flavors, and an assortment of tempura to pick from.

I decided to go for the beef curry, while my sister tried the creamy kabocha. I was initially planning to try the niku udon, but looking at some reviews on Yelp I went for the curry option instead.
Beef curry: The beef curry is quite flavorful, and made from a solid soup base for the udon. The udon was cooked reasonably well, and was the perfect texture.
Creamy kabocha: Also a very flavorful broth, definitely great for those who enjoy the pumpkin flavor. I personally enjoyed the creamy kabocha more, but it's not for everyone.
We also each got a fried tempura through the yelp check-in. Definitely a great supplement to the udon. The tempura was a bit over-battered in my opinion.

Overall, the udon was solid and the food came quickly. The prices were reasonable, particularly for something you're getting on market street. I'd return for another meal if I'm hungry for udon and I'm in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Michael L.

description:
Not sure how long it took for the ridiculous line to die down for good but it was a good 6 months or so before people realized they didn't want to spend $20 for a bowl of udon and tempura LOL

My favorite dish is their #2 Cold Udon. Perfectly fresh made noodles in a cold broth served with daikon, egg, green onion and nori with a lemon wedge. 

Sean who is the owner...i believe? Is amazing and super friendly! At times when i am at work and on my coffee break i would pass by Kagawa-Ya and i would see him inside prepping noodles and waving at me from the inside. 

Pretty big and decent place with great views for people watching on market street. They are located in the Uber building. i went in recently this week and noticed they are selling retail ! Super cute decal that i forgot to take a photo of. :) updates soon !
author: Anh T.

description: Sooooo..... If you've ever been to MARUGAME UDON this place is definitely not the same level I feel like. I ordered the beef niku udon, the broth was ok but the meat was very thickly sliced and not tender as beef udon should be. The udon itself seems like it was pre-cooked (?) hence it was a little bit over cooked because when i tried to pick it up with my chopsticks the noodle would most likely break. With that said I went with my coworkers and the ones that ordered the beef curry udon looked pretty good and flavorful. In terms of price I thought it was kind of expensive for what we got. I would say the price was around the same as MARUGAME UDON but there is a quality difference. Overall I would like to come back again and give the curry beef udon a try.
author: Nina Y.

description:
I tried 4 of their udon and my favorite is the creamy kabocha with chicken! You can order the bowl without the udon, too! The concept is very much like Chipotle, you're in and out after going on their assembly line. Do yourself a favor and order some broccoli tempura! It's really good! The noodles are the right amount of chewy and the flavors are really unique. Don't expect your typical udon here, because they combine flavors to create new items!

$5 Kitsune Udon on 4/12 for the first 100 diners!
author: Charlene F.

description:
I'm from LA but visited this Udon place 3 times and I keep craving it every time I'm on the plane ride home!!

I always order their veggie option. I love how quick they are with their service/ prep but the meal still tastes of great quality. Their soup base is rich and full of ingredients. Their udon noodle is soft yet firm enough to not soften up with the soup. I'm crazy for mushrooms and when I take a bite of the mushrooms in the soup, it's spilling with soup and flavor. This is my go-to spot EVERYTIME I visit SF and want a quick lunch.
author: Jaddis H.

description:
Decided to check out Kagawa during my lunch hour.  I see coworkers bring back their udon to the office pretty frequently so I figured I should give it a shot.  Plus, overcast weather makes me crave carbs and soup.

I dared to brave the weekday lunch rush but was pleasantly (and also slightly skeptical) surprised to see a pretty short line.  I did not do any prior research/Yelp stalking but thankfully Kagawa has TV menu boards that show photos of the dishes with a description.  I decided to try out the Creamy Kabocha w/ Chicken Udon.  

The vibe I got from Kagawa is like a trendy Morrison's Cafeteria.  You go down the line, place your order, take a couple steps to pick up said order, select any additional bites like tempura, and pay.

I did not have the highest expectation (cafeteria PTSD) but I did enjoy my bowl.  Typically I bring lunch from home, which has made me pretty choosy about where I go since I foot the bill.  Kagawa impressed me with their Kabocha so I'm down to explore their other udon creations.

PROS: 
- Fresh udon!  The noodles were definitely the star of the dish.  Great texture-- did not taste gummy or like they were sitting out.
- Chicken was super flavorful and had great texture.  Not overcooked or tough to eat which can be easily done in stew/curry-like dishes.
- Fast service
- Clean and spacious cafe

CONS: 
- Next time, I will ask for bonito flakes and nori on the side.  I did not travel far but both of those completed melted into an unappetizing looking gunk
- My dish was very bonito-forward (will ask for it on the side next time)
author: Cimma S.

description:
A little early to my interview, so I decided to check out this place if I'm going to be working in the area. Not many options to choose from, but what I like is how they cater to their customers. Quick, simple service for those who are on a time crunch during lunch.

The process is simple. Order what type of udon you want, grab a tray, pick up your bowl down the line, grab tempura/musubi/onigiri if you'd like, pay, and enjoy your meal. 

I tried the Kitsune udon and grabbed a beef onigiri. About $15 for lunch. Sounds about right for San Francisco. Anyways, I enjoyed my udon. The noodles were soft and the broth was flavorful without being too salty. My bowl didn't include any meat, but there were so many veggies that I didn't mind. I enjoyed my beef onigiri a couple hours later. It still tasted great. Sadly, even with instructions, I couldn't open it correctly. Practice makes perfect! I was expecting it to just have a filling in the middle, but all the ingredients are mixed in with the rice. You get all the ingredients in every bite.

When you're done, recycle, compost, trash, and place your tray at the window. Water is self serve with cups right by it. Extra condiments and tempura sauce next to the water. Quick, simple process for some great food!
author: Tiffany N.

description: Kagawa-Ya was the perfect spot to eat if you have a 30 minute lunch break and need to be in and then be out. The workers have speedy down to a science and the udon is good but not the best in SF. Would go back if I found myself downtown but probably wouldn't go out of my way to eat there as I've had better udon!
author: Sydney G.

description:
Just stopped by today for my second visit and ordered the Spicy Sweet Bean ( Zhajiang) Udon! It was on point and really tasty! So tasty that I ended up taking the leftover sauce home so I can add more noodles and have it as a second meal! The crisp daikon and cucumbers really elevated the flavors and made the dry Udon dish much tastier.  I love that this place is very innovative with their Udon menu and switch items up from time to time to keep things interesting! They make everything fresh in house, which is a rarity for most fast casual places. 

I got my bowl within 2 minutes of ordering (crazy fast!)

The staff is super friendly which is refreshing. The restaurant is really clean, bright and airy. I can't wait to come back and try the other flavors!
author: Kay H.

description: Pretty basic Udon place with a simple menu, some add-ons and chipotle-ish style of ordering. I've definitely had better but it seems like a pretty popular place as a lot of people were eating there. Went here once, glad I tried it but I wouldn't see myself coming here again.
author: Navdeep D.

description:
Had high hopes for this place, but it looks better than it tastes. And for $17 for udon ($14 Niku, $1.50 soft boiled egg, $1.50 shrimp tempura), it was too pricey for a bowl that wasn't anything special. The broth and noodles tasted like something you can buy at Ranch 99, and the beef was dry. The spam musubi was $3 and did not have flavor. I had to add sriracha to give it more taste. 

Sigh. The price you get for SF. If only it were as cheap and delicious as Marakume Udon in Hawaii or udon in Japan. I couldn't finish it so at least it gave me 2 meals.
author: Raquel Y.

description: Came here on a Thursday evening. It was pretty quiet due to it being a holiday the previous day. Had a hard time deciding which udon to choose from since the curry and creamy sounded really good. I opted for the original kitsune. Also got two tempura sides: shrimp and chicken. The udon was pretty good. The tofu skin was sweet and the broth had a good amount of flavor. I sorta regretted not going with the other broths as I think those would have more flavor. The shrimp was delicious as it was battered beautifully. I never had tempura chicken before and didn't like it. I wish it was karrage. Overall i would come back and try the other bowls.
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
Good fast causal go-to for good chewy udon noodz. Not the best you'll have, but very fulfilling. Ordered pickup once via Grubhub and walked-in another time and ordered takeout. 

I don't know if it just depends on who is working, but I like that they separate the noodles and soup in two bowls when I ordered takeout online. When I ordered takeout in-store they put everything in one bowl. Which makes the noodles soggy-ish. And you get less noodles. 

The Kitsune udon is my go-to. Light, flavorful broth. Clean. 

So far, I haven't enjoyed any of the tempura I've ordered (have tried the fish cake, egg, and broccoli). Will try again next time.
author: Ashley S.

description:
Late weeknight comfort

Curry beef udon
- delicious broth and good quality texture noodles
-soft boiled egg is always a good addition to noodles,  glad they had this option

Ambience is cafeteria style

With reasonable price for good food,  this place is one of those few places that we gotta keep alive in SF
author: Tina A.

description: A little expensive for what you get (even for downtown SF), but really solid, fresh food. The line moves quickly, and the atmosphere is clean and inviting. The tempura is awesome, and a great add-on to the main entrees. Will definitely be back!
author: James E.

description:
As an avid foodie and a pop-up restauranteur, I'll probably say some things that sound harsh but hopefully they utilize my feedback. 

There were several things I identified that could use some work. I breakdown noodle soup into three main components. The first is the broth, second is the noodles, and lastly is the toppings. Ill start with the soup. I ordered the Niku Udon. The broth is claimed to come from fish and beef. At first sip, I felt it lacked a true depth of flavor. It wasn't salty enough nor was there enough beef or fish flavor. It also was extremely sweet which might have overpowered any natural beef or fish sweetness. The noodles are precooked and rolled into batches. When you order, they do a quick parboil to reheat the noodles. Since the noodles sit on a rack, the internal temperature and external temperature is different. Even after the parboil, the noodles aren't completely hot. One thing I did like about the noodles was the texture. It was chewy and bouncy at each bite. You've got to eat fast though or else it will start to soften and crumble. Lastly, the niku beef was so overcooked, it was like chewing beef jerky. Kagawa-Ya separates the beef and broth in different heated containers; however, this just allows the cooks beef to continue to cook which brings it to the point of over cooking. In addition, since Niku beef is supposed to be braised, they should probably use meat that has more fat content. 

At $14 a bowl of Niku Udon, I expected a lot more. I've had plenty of experience eating in asian countries where Maragume Udon is like their McDonalds. I don't think I'll venture back here to eat unless they change the process they make their beef and broth. And for those that want extra udon, it is $3. So at $30 for my two Niku udons and an extra portion, I don't think it was quite worth it. The food they presented to me more closely aligns to a price tag of $6 per bowl. Save your money and go get poke at the Twitter market. I have attached a picture from Kagawa-Ya with the dry beef :(
author: Jason W.

description:
Ate here after some drinking down the street at Beer Hall. Had not been here before and only just pulled it up on my Yelp app while drinking a beer with my friend.

We were glad to see plenty of seating inside on a Friday night. Didn't know it was cafeteria style but I was pleasantly surprised once I paid up and got my food! 

I ordered the tomato broth udon with shiitake mushrooms (vegetarian option). I wasn't feeling too much meat that night and actually really glad I got the veggie option! It was really good mmmm. I also grabbed a Spam musubi for an additional $3. My total came out to around $13. 

The biiiig hoooottt bowl of udon was really nice to have on such a cold SF night. As others have said, the tomato broth was more of a paste consistency. It was like eating pasta almost - but it was great! I also agree with one reviewer that it was reminiscent of all the sweet Asian tomato sauces I've had in my childhood (and adulthood, who am I kidding). My family will sometimes make 'Asian style' pasta with a sweet tomato sauce with hot dog and mushrooms. My veggie udon reminded me of just that! 

Yum! Simple and affordable for the area this place is in. Right under Uber headquarters (must be busy during lunchtime!)
author: Shanise M.

description:
If only my office was closer to Kagawa-Ya, I would come more often for lunch.  ha!  Maybe it is better that I am in the Embarcadero *wink wink*

This is my second visit!

Came here on a Tuesday, 12:30pm.
Simple concept - cafeteria style.  Take a tray, order your udon, slide down a bit to the opening so your bowl of noodles can be handed to you.  If you want some tempura, grab a plate and help yourself (using tongs of course!)

I ordered the Creamy Kabocha Chicken - and it was SO GOOD!!  The noodles are perfectly cooked - thick, chewy and perfectly satisfying!  The broth is teeny bit sweet probably bec of the pumpkin squash.  Note- this is NOT curry.  It may look like it, but it has cream to thicken the broth.  The green onion + nori topping added a really nice touch!

As for tempura, I decided to just try one - the sweet egg... delicious!

I enjoyed every last drop of my broth and every single udon noodle.  I would definitely come back.  Only thing I wish was for the broth to be a bit hotter, but no biggie.

The place was spacious and clean.  Price point was fair given that this is located in San Francisco.  Staff was friendly.
author: Margaret W.

description:
Yaki too.   Like the food and service.   Yaki plate was huge. Place is pretty bare inside. 

I have and will keep coming back.
author: Larry W.

description: Still coming here, its always on my radar. I'm not a huge mushroom fan but the mushroom udon broth is wonderful.
author: barbara r.

description:
Creme of clam tasted like potatoes.  Not a clam in sight.  The bacon crunchiness to offset the warm guey noodles was a nice touch.

But at a $12 price point I wanted clans, not to be switched to potatoe which is what the noodle should gave been called.

Though the review is biased downwards it's because mainly of false advertising and cost.  Add tax and could tempura it was $17 for a super small bow of Campbell's soup.
author: David H.

description:
I finally go to try Kagawa-Ya Udon in Mid-Market past The Market building.  You line up and tell one person what dish you want, they make it, you pick it up and then grab maybe some more food, and pay.  Super easy and Fast!

I got #5 Creamy Kabocha w/ Chicken Udon $12.  Sign says broth contains chicken & fish, Pumpkin squash broth, chicken, cream, green onions, nori & bonito flakes.  It's pretty tasty, chicken can be dry, but with the soup it made it fine, tasty udon noodles - bouncy and chewy, not sure I tasted the kabocha I guess it's mushed up really well in there.

I also got a beef Onigiri $3 - I didn't follow the directions on the plastic sleeve on how to open it so it was difficult and not how it was suppose to be, it fell apart and I just dumped it into my soup.  Tasty enough.

They sell out quick on the Spam Musubi $3 - so get there early if you can.

They take credit cards, think I saw a bathroom need code - didn't use it.

Help yourself to free ice water on the other side, and Rooster sauce, Katsu sauce, Tempura sauce on the side table too.  Bus your table after you are done.

Hrs: M-F 11-2:30pm, 5:30-8:30pm

Next time I want to try: Cream of Clam & Leeks $12
author: Ann L.

description:
Eh, I've had better udon. 

Popped in for lunch yesterday at Kagawa as the photos looked really good and I hadn't had udon in a while. Unfortunately the result was lackluster and just ok. 

The concept makes sense for the location (next to Uber and Twitter) but, it felt a bit to cafeteria to me and didn't make for a great experience. I ordered the #3 (beef broth, shredded beef/onions) and added a couple pieces of tempura. The broth wasn't as flavorful as I had hoped but, the udon noodles and tempura were pretty good. 

All in all it's not a place I'd visit again but, I understand the appeal for those lunchers in a rush.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Dinner review. Udon-ya.

Ordered:
#1 - Fish broth
#6 - Kabocha broth
Tempura crab
Tempura fish cake
Tempura shrimp
Curry potato

Overall, not many udon shops in the city. Probably the best option. "As good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Pro tip: if you check in on Yelp, you get a free tempura of your choice. I would give this place 3.5 stars if I could. I came here during dinnertime on a Wednesday, and there was hardly anyone in the restaurant which was refreshing, given most places in SF always have a wait. 

The set-up of the restaurant is like an udon bar where you get a tray, order your meal, receive it, and find seating on your own. It felt like a model of the famous Marukame udon bar in Honolulu. 

I ordered the kitsune udon with a poached egg and a shrimp tempura on the side. The broth was not hot enough for me, and the noodles were still a bit chewy. The broth was decent, but I prefer a stronger taste. There was a good amount of food though, with ample veggies and wakame too. It was a decent, convenient meal close to Civic Center Bart. I also liked how they gave us free onigiri when they were closing to avoid letting it go to waste.
author: Victoria L.

description: Great for those who has problems making choices since the choices are few.   I had the sweet bean with ground beef udon.  I enjoyed the home made el dente udon.  One bowl will satisfy your appetite, it did for me.  Cafeteria style, stand in line to order.  They give your bowl if udon to you immediately with or without extra cilantro.   Check in yelp and you get one piece of free tempera.  They keep replenishing so it should be new.  My friend had the beef soup udon.  It smells great.  Choose your drink.  Pay. Find a table and slurp up.  Bus your table.
author: Helen L.

description:
Parking is super difficult here, since it's on the same street as the Westfield Mall and right next to the Uber corporate office. We came in at around 5:30pm on a Tuesday, and there was plenty of seating. The restaurant is really big and there's plenty of seating. When ordering, you first choose which udon soup you want, and then there's a section where you can choose which tempuras you want. 

I went for the niku udon and it was a good size, with a lot of beef and onions (almost 1/3 of the portion was meat, which was nice if you like meat in your noodles like I do). The broth was flavorful and light, and I enjoyed the noodles, which are supposedly handmade. However, I have had fresh udon at other places, and this spot was just alright. The broth and noodles didn't stand out too much, but it's a good place for a quick lunch or dinner. However, it's pretty pricey--the niku was about $13 and it didn't come with the poached egg; that has to be added for an extra price. The food was definitely a 3.5/5 but I am rounding it to a 3 because of the price and parking. 

I would definitely come back if I was in the area, but I would't make a trip to the city just for it.
author: Sandra S.

description:
I finally got the chance to come back to Kagawa-Ya. I thoroughly enjoyed my Kitsune udon. Delicious, comforting broth with fresh udon, seaweed and sweet soybean skin. I added a few pieces of tempura - light and crunchy. 

Since my Kutsune lunch was so satisfying, i ordered the Spicy Beef Tan Tan Udon to go. I just ate it for lunch and it's become another favorite! The broth is spicy, rich and flavorful; the bean sprouts provided a nice crunch and the cilantro added a fresh note (yes, I like cilantro). 

I will definitely be back! But I won't know what to order; Kitsune, Spicy Beef Tan Tan, Curry...
author: Mary L.

description:
Pricy and overrated. 

The noodles are made quickly, but besides that selling point, Kagawa-Ya Udon does not have much else. I tried the Niku Udon, which came to around 15.19 with no add-ons, and consisted of a very simple bowl of udon. There was plenty of beef, but it and the broth were not very flavorful. The noodles were also really soft, even though I ate it immediately afterwards. 

It's just not worth it, unless you are in a hurry, as there are so many better places nearby.
author: Hannah H.

description: I stumbled upon this place by happenstance.  Among my numerous trips to Japan the one thing I truly missed was a good bowl of udon noodles.  The place is in an economically upon and coming area - but is new & clean inside.  The staff was nice and smiles!  The portions good sized, but pricey for udon.  The taste wasn't quite like Japan (maybe a little sweeter broth - could quite finger it) but good for the states. I tried the beef with a shrimp tempura piece.  Tempura wasn't life changing - in the US the batter is almost always too heavy & such was the case here.  But all and all my noodles tasted good for my American pallet. And that's what really counts.  You'll never get an actual Japanese taste in the US as the chemical composition of water is different (for starters) which impacts almost everything served.  But if I found the place delicious and am very likely to return.
author: Robert C.

description:
Went here for lunch and got the niku udon plus some tempura (fish cake, shrimp, and a giant zuchinni). Both yummy. The broth was flavorful and they gave a lot of beef. The tempura was crunchy and perfectly cooked.  Service was quick and the place was clean.  I also took a spam musubi but was too full to eat it.  It's sitting on my desk waiting for me to demolish it still. 

My friend got the creamy udon and a curry potato tempura. She said the potato needed more curry. 

If you are going to compare this to the amazing Marakume Udon in Honolulu you will find that it's not better, but a good substitute. I would go here again. My only wish is they expand their hours since it's not easy to get out here on a workday and to expand their tempura selection.
author: Joanne T.

description:
I really like the soup at Kagawa-Ya Udon and I'm happy they have a spot on Market. 

It's cafeteria-style with just a few options on the menu for quick service. I've had the kitsune udon and the pumpkin one. Both are delicious and very filling. The only one I can't eat is the soup that has beef in it. I know I'll have to come back and try the veggie option and the cold udon. 

I find the broth in the kitsune to be comforting, and I like the different textures from the tofu skin, tempura bits, and the seaweed. The tempura, after awhile, gets soaked into the soup so I prefer to dine in when choosing this option.  And the udon itself is cooked perfectly. The noodles are thick and have a good bite. 

They also have assorted tempura for $1.50 each. As my coworker says, my eye be pimpin my brain because I always order at least 2 pieces of tempura, but can barely finish my lunch because the soup is so filling! Luckily I didn't get the musubi. That would've put me over the edge. So far I've had the shrimp tempura, curry potato, and the fish cake. Crunchy and it's not too greasy. 

The space is open and very clean. The are different table set ups so it's easy for groups or solo diners to sit among each other. 

The soups are around $11, and go up from there. I find it's a good place to easily get lunch, or dinner after work if you're really hungry, in the area, and just can't wait to eat.
author: Vira P.

description:
It's okay. 

I ordered the Niku Udon, added an egg, and then picked up the fish cake tempura, chicken skewer, spam musubi, and a beef rice ball for later. 

Niku Udon - As most people have described, the udon itself is chewy and has a pleasant texture. What's really lacking here is the broth flavor and dry, unpleasant, flavorless, beef. The broth is too mild to deliver any flavor to the noodles, maybe a bit more dashi? Beef was horribly cooked (or possibly the wrong cut of meat is chosen here) and absolutely did not warrant the $14 base price of this bowl.

Fish cake tempura - Added to my bowl, tasted very delicious while lightly soaked with the broth. Didn't have any excess oily bits. Their tempura is probably the real star here.

Chicken skewer - Flavorful and juicy. Nothing unique, but tasted amazing in comparison to the "ok" udon.

Spam musubi - They've folded in a lot of furikake, not sure it does much though. It's salty meat and rice, you can't really screw this up.

Niku rice ball - Okay, I'd just like to clarify that had I known the meat in my udon was going to be dry and gross I would have avoided this entirely. This only gets its own section still because this was the weirdest rice ball I've ever had in my entire life? Again folded in with furikake, but the meat, instead of being in the center, was also folded in with the rice? It was literally all over the place and just made the entire thing taste like college ruled paper. Disgusting.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here, but if I'm in the area I might pick up a piece of tempura or something.

Edit: To the owner, thank you for responding so quickly. While I appreciate the suggestion, I don't believe a curry (or other) udon is the appropriate solution when the udon I was looking forward to was so vastly different. The larger problem overall was the beef, not the broth.
author: Nikki L.

description:
Ready to go, fast casual udon. I'm a fan. Small menu, so for those of you who complain about not having options.. uhhh, this is so you get in, eat and get out. Go elsewhere. You're missing the concept.
I personally don't mind a small focused set menu. They also say no substitutions. 

I would say Kagawa-Ya is decently priced for the area, but it can definitely add up. 
I had the beef curry udon ($13) but added a soft poached egg (additional $1.50 I think). I decided what the hell, why not go all out and picked up spam musubi ($3) and a Hawaiian Sun drink. After tip and tax, I somehow blew $22 for lunch.  I'm a big eater so I finished everything and was left satisfied. 

Beef curry was quite good. I enjoyed it because it wasn't overly salty and the beef was incredibly tender. Worth the $13. Noodles were al dente. Soft poached egg was delicious and worth it. 

Spam musubi had too much rice and I think the spam could've been grilled longer. Will be back for niku udon and curry croquette!
author: Susy C.

description: Fantastic udon at very reasonable prices. The richness of the broths and the freshness of the noodles are both excellent. Love Kagawa-Ya!
author: Eric B.

description: Come before 12pm to avoid long lines. Check in for a free tempura. All broths are pre-made and they just pour it over the udon which is made when ordered. I got the Cream of Clam and Leeks Udon and I have to say it was so bomb. It was like clam chowder with udon lol. Sad I think there were only a couple of pieces of clam. I thought it tasted pretty good. Portion was good, since udon is pretty filling. I would definitely come back for lunch.
author: Benita M.

description: I hate ranting but I think I could get similar udon at any other Japanese restaurant that doesn't solely focus on udon.  The tempura was also dinky, not hot, and not fresh.  Udon isn't high on my list in general but after eating here, it makes me want udon mizugo in jtown even more.
author: Vince L.

description: Not my favorite place but I live nearby so went there to try it out because my wife was sick and I didn't feel like cooking after a long day of work. Overall, this place is a nice place for busy techy who work near by. But a place to go out of my way to eat there I don't recommend it.
author: Michael Q.

description:
I came here in a hurry with a 30 minute lunch in between meetings since I was in the area and I heard that this place is super quick - and it is! I'm really amazed at how fast it took for me to be in & out of this place with a satisfied tummy :) 

I ordered the creamy kabocha udon and the creamy croquette. The broth was very rich and flavorful, but did not taste fatty and oily like ramen broth. The texture of the udon was great as well. The creamy croquette was just OK to me, but I think I'll give it another try next time - maybe the regular croquette. The bowl however, was pretty small though and a little pricey for its size, however it is super convenient and I would definitely come back if I'm in a hurry and don't have much time for lunch. The service was also great. The cashier was really friendly and helpful. Overall, great lunch spot, especially if you're going for a quick lunch.
author: Bailey L.

description:
Was looking forward to this place since it opened, but never had the opportunity to be in the neighborhood until this past weekend. The menu prices were not the cheapest for udon, $9-$15. I opted for the #1 kitsune udon (no meat, but had greens and tofu) and with a check-in offer of a free piece of tempura. I got the chicken tempura and a curry potato croquette making the total to about $13. 

The tempura and potato were cold and didn't taste very fresh as it was probably sitting out for a while. It was a Saturday afternoon, so probably not as fast-paced and busy as a weekday. There was a good amount of udon and the greens were good, but the broth was super salty. 

The location is pretty close to Twitter and a bunch of other tech companies, so I can imagine it gets pretty busy during week day lunch time. Definitely not worth the trek of going to the area specifically to try this place.
author: Christina G.

description:
This is probably one of my new favorite spots in the city :) we stumbled upon this udon restaurant yesterday and boy I must say I'm so happy we did . This establishment reminds me of the set up of marukame udon  in Honolulu Hawaii . Like marukame they also hand make their udon noodles every few hours . You can tell the put a lot of pride into their Craftsmanship . My only gripe about this place is My soup was not extremely hot and i received a under cooked Broccoli tempura :( 
Will be back to try our more goodies
author: Monica M.

description:
Kagawa-Ya Udon is perfect for a quick and casual bite to eat right before heading to a show. My friend and I had tickets to the Nutcracker on a Wednesday night, and I picked this spot since I've been meaning to check it out and it was conveniently nearby.

Ordering is super simple. You choose a base udon (they have a decent selection with 7 options) and then grab any additional tempura toppings you want. 

I wasn't that hungry, so I went with the basic kitsune udon ($9.50), which comes with dashi broth, sweet soybean skin, wakame seaweed, tempura crunch and green onions. The kitsune udon doesn't come with any meat, so I also helped myself to some shrimp and fish cake tempura.

To me, udon is a simple but delicious meal. The hot dashi broth really hit the spot for a cold winter's night in San Francisco, and the shrimp and fish cake tempura helped add some flavor to what would have otherwise been a bland bowl of udon.

The space is nice and big too. It was well lit and had a very modern look to it. Given that it was a random Wednesday evening, it was pretty empty and we were able to take our pick of seating.
author: Dianna H.

description: Good, casual spot for a quick lunch if you're feeling something soupy.  I got the Creamy Kabocha w/ Chicken Udon and it was nice and creamy (as advertised!), with the chicken being super tender and the noodles having a great spring to them.  My only wish was that the soup was actually hot as it was more of a lukewarm temperature but overall good flavor.  I also got a side of the tamago tempura (really interesting as I haven't seen this often anywhere else and the sweetness was a nice offset to the rich Udon though a bit warmer temp would've been nice) and chicken kara-age which was fine but again not super fresh.  $12 for the udon and $1.50 per side so a bit on pricier side at $16 for lunch but sadly par for the course in SF.  All in all I'll likely be back to try other udons and sides!
author: Aaron K.

description:
I love that an udon place has opened up in this area.  However, prices and quality of the udon is a bit disappointing.  I ordered the #1 Kitsune.  It's the cheapest option and the most basic udon with two pieces of soybean skin.  However, the price increases when you add on items.  Each piece of tempura or egg costs $1.50, which is quite pricey.  Taste-wise, the broth itself is very nice, but the udon was a bit too soft me.

I might come back if I'm ever wanting a bowl of hot noodles, otherwise, there are better price options for lunch.
author: Karen L.

description:
This is one of your semi-fast food joints that does a solid job, but isn't anything to write home about. Also, when we got there, they ran out of noodles, so the quick eat draw got thrown out the window when we had to wait for the next batch to be done. 

The noodles were well done, but the broth was a bit on the sweeter side. Also, compared to marugame, I would have preferred to be able to add my own green onions, tempura topping, etc. but, the tempura here was better, imo, than marugame. It was fresher tasting and crispier - I tried the fried fish cake and highly recommend it. I got the niku ramen, and it came with LOTS of meat...I would argue too much and that the ratio was off, but I know that doesn't affect most people.

Recommend for a solid quick stop if you're in the area, but not worth navigating to just to try.
author: Annie S.

description: My friends and I were really excited about an udon place opening up in SF. All in all, the food wasn't bad, but it was a little pricey and lacked the refinement I would've expected from the price and the hype. The noodles themselves were fine, but the broth was seriously lacking. Though udon broth is not as rich as ramen broth, it should still be flavorful and unique. I didn't feel that came through. The choice of broth and toppings were good, but it just adds to the price.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night before catching a show at the SHN Orpheum. I arrived a little bit after 6:30 and was slightly worried because they closed at 7PM. Ordering was super easy and the food came out fast. We ordered the Kitsune Udon and the Niku udon and got a spam musubi, sweet egg tempura, and a curry croquette. I didn't think anything special about the noodles. I thought they would boil the noodles when I ordered it but what I saw is that the noodles were already boiled waiting on a steam bed of some sorts. 

The broth for the kitsune was very good and I liked the kitsune although different than what I had before. Their kitsune is a sweet soy sauce flavor which I liked. 

The Niku udon was okay. The broth was too sweet for my taste. It reminded me of kbbq marinated bulgogi but udon style.

Spam musubi was good but I thought the proportions were off. Lots of rice compared to the thickness of the spam. Made it seem healthier though.

The sweet egg tempura I got because it seemed interesting. It was okay, wish it was softer and air-re-er (I don't know how to spell). 

The curry croquette was just okay too, I've had better at Nijiya market. Probably would not get that again.

Overall pretty good and glad I made it in time!
author: Avita S.

description: Great meal for the price and super yummy. Not a huge noodle fan but this place is one of my favs. Local ownership, great menu options, and friendly staff make this a place you'll want to keep coming back to.
author: Katherine M.

description: We really like Kagawa-Ya.  We have been there a a bunch of times and they have never disappointed.  It has become our go-to comfort food spot. The noodles are amazing. Try the curry too! It's my favorite.
author: J D.

description:
On a week with no work I had to pop into Fatted Calf for something, and decided I'd have lunch nearby.  I chose to eat at Kagawa-Ya since it's only open on weekdays.

This is sort of like Marukame-light.  Last time I was in Hawaii I had Marukame Udon and it was great and a fun concept.  You get your udon (with handmade noodles) and a selection of tempura to accompany if you so choose.

That's basically what you get here as well.  I don't know if there's quite the selection of tempura but otherwise it's pretty much the same experience.

Everything I had was tasty and being that I came in at the tail-end of lunch hour I was able to get my food pretty much immediately.  I got my kitsune udon and 3 pieces of tempura for around $15.  If I find myself in SF on a weekday I'd return for sure.
author: Brent T.

description:
Had the opportunity to eat here for dinner during my short stay in SF. I ordered udon with some added spice and it was pretty damn tasty. The wife had the curry udon and she thoroughly enjoyed it. I'm usually not a fan of batter but I have their tempura a try after hearing my wife recommend it and it was definitely worth it. If you are in the area I highly recommend you try their udon! 
And their service was pretty good. We had a lot of questions about the food and they were very friendly and offered some sound suggestions.
author: Howard T.

description:
Very clean and spacious!

Beware they ask you not to make substitutions and just choose a number option. The unique part is the little tempura bar they have set up right before you hit the cashier station. I think people should just get a separate little plate for your tray if they want to add on tempura pieces otherwise it gets soggy from the broth when you place it in your bowl.
Also something I didn't realize until halfway through my meal was that there is a water/condiment table around the corner from the ordering area. I guess I missed it as I walked in. If you don't notice it at first like me then you will notice it when you are bussing your dishes because you pass the condiment station to get to the dishpit area.

In terms of the food, I found the #5 to be a bit bland but the over all dish was very filling. Because of the kabocha as the broth it was heavier and creamier. I also added the rectangular sweet egg tempura to my dish. That was interesting and I hadn't seen that before. It tasted like a sweet omelet rolled up. The eggplant looked like it was cut in a very unique way and not just sliced. I'll try something different next time!
author: Laura Y.

description: Had great udon. This place is a good pick me up on a cold date. Also love spam musbi, can't get enough.
author: Mike J.

description:
Since there are probably a decent number of people familiar with it, I'll compare Kagawa to Marukame Udon in Hawaii (which is usually in Yelps top 100).  Kagawa-Ya is a cafeteria style udon restaurant in the heart of SF.  It has a good variety of udon choices as well as tempura.  I was even surprised to see spam musubis!  

While the pricing isn't all that cheap, the portions for their udon are pretty large.  The tempura is about the right price at $1.50 per piece (regardless of vegetable or shrimp tempura).  Spam musubi is quite pricey at $3.  I ended up going with the Kitsune Udon which came in at $9.5.  The only udon under $10 just fyi.  Anyways, it was alright.  The broth had a great dashi flavor, noodles were cooked great.  The inari was just ok, a bit too big, would've been nice if it had been cut in half or something.  The inari also felt rather thick.  The shrimp tempura was okay, seemed like frozen pre-battered kind.  The vegetable tempura was great, I was glad they had pumpkin tempura available.  As for the spam musubi, it was good, the rice was seasoned with furikake which added some extra flavor.  It didn't appear to have any kind of teriyaki sauce like you might find in some musubis.

Overall, it is no Marukame Udon, however, it is a good attempt at the cafeteria-style udon restaurant.  The food here is great if you're craving udon, especially since there aren't many restaurants in the Bay that specifically specialize in udon.  Personally, I wish the udon had a small-sized available, that way I could eat more tempura.  The udon portions are quite large.
author: Bryson L.

description:
I ordered the Niku udon. The broth was good, not heavy but flavorful. Meat was pretty tender and complemented the soup well. Additionally, the udon was a good consistency. The egg was a little too runny for my taste, but others may like it to seep into the soup the way it did. 

I think the only real drawback is that, despite being peak dinner time, they ran out of udon noodles, and some guests either left or had to wait upwards of 6-7 minutes, like me. (This is in addition to waiting in line while others ordered, so our wait time was probably like 15 min for what should be a 5-minute deal). My friends and I chose to eat at Kagawa-Ya because we were in a rush and knew we could get a quick yet delicious bite before heading off to the ballet a few blocks away. Unfortunately, the precious time we lost waiting for the udon to cook meant we had to gulp  down our food as fast as possible without really enjoying it. 

Of course, once the noodles were done cooking, everything else went as planned in a timely manner. Not the best first experience, but I'd come back!
author: Jennifer L.

description: First time here and i can already tell that this will be a regular place for me when it comes to udon. The noodle is excellently cooked not over cooked like other places broth is seasoned well salt is over powering the main ingredients of the dish and plus they serve soft boiled egg which  i dont see all the time in any noodle noodle place ive been. Just a heads up this is a self service noodle place not a full service restaurant but who cares  as long the place is clean and serve a really good food
author: Allan A.

description:
Yesterday, I was walking to The Market in the Twitter building to grab a quick bite when I saw Le Boss walk out of Kagawa-Ya. 

Le Boss: "Hey, you try this new udon place yet?"
Me *SHOCKED*: "No, I haven't...I'm going later this week."

Le Boss: "You gotta try it, it's soft opening today and grand opening tomorrow!"

I stood there in a state of shock. 

Who is this hip, foodie guy? 

I guess you can't judge a person by their favorite restaurant, even if it's iconically horrendous (Sinbad's: https://www.yelp.com/biz/sinbads-pier2-restaurant-san-francisco-2). At least it's famous for something?

Even though I had plans to visit Kagawa-Ya later this week, I decided to stop by yesterday to give it a try. Kagawa-Ya's specialty is their housemade udon which is served 5 different ways ($9.50-$14): warm dashi broth, cold dashi broth, braised beef, beef curry, and kabocha. You can add a side of tempura (shrimp, kobocha, sweet potato, broccoli rabe, or tamago) or an soft boiled egg for +$1.50 each. If you're not feeling noodles, they have a curry rice option (beef or vegetarian). They also have sides like spam musubi, inari, and onigiri. For those with MSG sensitivities, the staff told me that the curry contains MSG but the dashi and creamy kabocha doesn't. 

It's a fast casual eatery - line up, grab a tray, order by number, watch your order being assembled, grab a plate and pick out your choice of tempura under the heat lamps, grab your udon/rice bowl, and pay. I appreciated that the tip choices were 5%, 10%, and 15% unlike some fast casual spots who program the tip choices as 18%, 20%, and 25%. I always tip for fast casual but you shouldn't expect customers to pay the same tip as a sit-down restaurant when they're having to serve and clean up after themselves. 

I love kabocha so I naturally gravitated towards #5 Creamy Kabocha Udon w/ roasted kabocha, dashi broth, cream, nori, green onions, bonito ($11) and added tempura shrimp, kabocha, and sweet potato (+$1.50 each): http://bit.ly/2p66i5C. Since the udon just contains noodles and broth (no kabocha), I highly recommend adding tempura for a full meal. 

I really enjoyed the creamy kabocha broth which was deliciously creamy with a good savory sweetness. The housemade udon noodles were al-dente but were missing that toothsome chewy bite. The tempura was nicely battered and fried producing a light, airy crunchy exterior. It was perfect for dipping into the creamy kabocha broth. I just wish the tempura was warm. Even though the tempura was sitting under the heat lamp, it was tepid.  

Service was friendly and fast. I was in and out in less than 20 minutes making it the perfect quick lunch spot. My only suggestion is to place the water dispenser out front so the cashier doesn't have to be bothered with filling cups when they're ringing up a customer.  

Formerly Happy Donuts, the new space is spacious and contemporary. There's seating for about 40 - two-tops and communal tables. I like that there's an open kitchen so everything is transparent.  

Kagawa-Ya is a great addition to the Mid-Market lunch scene especially on cold, foggy days that call for a piping hot bowl of soup. But, just like with most of the new fast casual eateries in the city, it's not cheap. It was $18.50 out the door for lunch (no drink). I guess the $20s is the new $10s [lunch]?
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Not sure what to expect at first... but this place is a cute restaurant on market street. It's good for lunch breaks and In betweens. I ordered the mushroom udon and it was super delicious!!!!
author: Summer M.

description: Everything already made, just needs to be mixed in. A decent menu and options. Overall, I was happy with my udon but it wasn't special or anything. Felt that the udon and tempuras were overpriced! So given that, 3 stars for decent/ average udon in the city
author: JJ W.

description:
If I have to describe this place in a few words, it would be 'udon fast food' but don't the fast food part fool you because this place still has the fresh udon noodles, flavorful broth and jam packed with meat and whatever topping that comes with your particular order. 

Other than the complaint that this place closes too early (7pm on weekday), this place is a great and fast place to grab dinner. You grab a tray, tell the person which udon you want (menu on the board) and within 1 minute, the noodle, broth, meat and topping is all scoop inside a bowl and passed to you. You can then proceed to add a half boiled/poached egg and grab individual fried tempura ($1.50/piece) to your liking. Katsu, tempura sauce on the side when you're down paying.

I got #3 Niku udon, which was essentially beef + onions. The broth was very rich and flavorful. They were pretty generous with the amount of beef, to the point where I couldn't finish it. I added a half boiled egg, and it was the perfect consistency.  Additionally also got some tempura-- which were still crispy regardless of the fact that we got the last pick of the last batch. 

Even though you don't get direct table service, the customer service here was excellent. The dispenser was out of tempura sauce, and they were unable to make a fresh batch since we came right before closing. Came back around and they poured out what was remaining in the dispenser for us to use. 

TLDR; Fast food style udon with fresh ingredients. Overall good food and would definitely come back again. Great service!
author: Jenny N.

description:
This place is dope! I've never really been into Udon, but I know every time I see one of my friends in Hawaii eating Marukame, I want tempura. What's not to love about tempura? 

It can be on the pricey side, I think I ended up paying $20+, but I got a kitsune udon (beef sounded too heavy at the moment) with a bunch of tempura and a spam misubi and poached egg. Very tasty, and now I like udon, but probably only from places that have tempura (since tempura is awesome).

It's too bad this place is so far away. We need one of these down in the south bay so I don't always have to go up to SF to eat this :).
author: Kenny N.

description:
Fast casual udon bar with a bunch of soup choices and an à la carte tempura bar.  Seemed like comparable quality to Ramen Bar.  A strangely huge space given the sparse seating; hope they aren't being gouged in rent.

Niku Udon: The udon noodles were large, firm and delicious.  The broth had a heavy ginger streak with some beefiness mixed in.  The meat was just ok.  It was like something at Yoshinoya, but clumped together and not as thinly sliced.  I kinda prefer the Yoshinoya beef more, though everything else in the Niku Udon was better.

Curry Potato: A creamy curried potato mash deep fried in the shape of a hash brown.  Quite filling and bursting with texture/flavor contrasts.

Shrimp Tempura: Pretty much what you'd expect.  Compared to the Curry Potato, it wasn't as good for being at the same price point.

Beef Niku Onigiri: Interesting presentation where the seaweed was wrapped in plastic and then wrapped around the rice/beef mixture.  The pro is that you are guaranteed a crispy non-soggy seaweed wrap.  The con is that you probably can't wrap an onigiri like a professional.  The filling was just ok; felt a bit skimpy on the beef since it look like just flecks.
author: Adam B.

description:
Niku (beef) udon, $14
Taste: broth has a little sweet taste. Beef was soft
shrimp tempera, $1.50
sweet potato, $1.50
Total plus tax: $18.44
I don't hate it but I don't love it. Environment was cool but not worth it. Still hungry :(
author: Jasmin T.

description: Good size bowl of udon but broth was not hot enough for me.  Check in on YELP and get one free piece of tempura.
author: Agnes K.

description:
Walked by this place a couple of times as I was visiting friends in Uber/Square. Turns out they share a building! It's right off Market, so it's hard to miss. 

Got the curry udon, and boy did it taste like heaven. 

If you're a udon lover like me, you should definitely try this place out! Has nice wooden tables for nice instagram photos too.
author: Cheechee L.

description: Awesome! Great finesse and skill in the dashi broth, fried tofu, tempura, and fresh made noodles! People are so nice too! Their kitsune udon is the taste of my childhood! Great job!
author: Young I.

description: Overpriced noodles and soup. While the broth is kind of light, there's not much to be desired by this. I can see it it's a cold day this might be a good place but otherwise i would not recommend this place
author: Jaymon H.

description:
This place is bamb. 

Tried the kabocha/chicken udon and their monthly special - the spam fried rice waffle stuffed with karaage 

I was impressed. The kabocha broth was delicious and creamy with the perfect ratio of noodles, soup, chicken and garnish. My eyes were bigger than my stomach and I was unable to try the SFRW and took it home.

But wow - it was delicious. Such a creative combination of ingredients with a wonderful presentation. I hope they cycle it back into their specials or add it into their permanent menu!!  

A lot of folks complain about the prices but uh, I'm sure their rent is through the roof! Things to consider, yelpers... I'll definitely be back!
author: Fuu C.

description:
You know, I can't believe my unbelievable luck of having two new udon places open up in SF during the past year. Udon is one of my favorite foods, and to have smacked right on Market Street makes it even better. I was very excited to try out Kagawa-Ya, and I came here on a weekday evening with a friend to satisfy my hunger for udon. I was expecting it to be really crowded here since it's smacked right in the middle of where all the tech companies are and we came during dinner hours but was surprised when it was at 20% capacity. The good thing about that was that we got to choose our seats, and we decided to sit on the stools by the window peering outside. 

We then went up to the line and ordered our respective udon dishes. I decided to go for the Beef Curry Udon and for the tempura I got the sweet egg tempura, vegetable fritter, and the curry potato. They have a wide selection of tempura and I like how you're able to just choose one of whatever tempura you want instead of having multiple of the same tempura. I sampled the beef curry udon first and was very pleased with my choice, as the curry tasted fantastic and the tender beef just falls apart once I bit into it. What I like even more than the beef personally was the potatoes, and curry is always better with potatoes. One thing about the curry udon is that it wasn't as thick as I would have liked, and this was honestly more personal preference than anything. I moved onto the tempura next, and I started with the sweet egg tempura. I think the sweet egg tempura was alright, but to be honest, I never had a sweet egg tempura before, and I think it's more likely that I just don't like sweet eggs as a tempura in general. The vegetable fritter, on the other hand, was to my liking, and it was pretty crunchy and was a nice meld of vegetables. However, my favorite tempura was the curry potato, since it had a soft crusty exterior and a very soft interior. The curry flavor wasn't strong in the curry potato, but that could be because I was eating the beef curry udon at the same time, which probably overwhelmed the subtle curry flavor in the curry potato. Nevertheless, I felt very satisfied with the curry potato.

Overall, I was very pleased with the meal, and I really like how they gave a generous helping of beef and potatoes with the udon. One thing about the price is, it's actually more than what I would expect to pay for udon, and the curry udon alone was $14. I can somewhat justify this since there were very generous portions of udon, and I did feel really bloated after eating it. I would definitely come back here again, and I could see myself ordering the Creamy Kabocha with Chicken Udon, or the Cream of Clam & Leeks Udon the next time I come here. As an aside, I wish they had more cold udon options besides the regular Cold Udon, and hopefully, they would expand their repertoire of cold udon. Other than that, I would highly recommend Kagawa-Ya for anyone with a craving for good udon in SF.
author: Nelson X.

description:
(Note: I have a very sensitive palate. This means I don't like spicy foods, but I can taste the difference between generic, mass-produced noodles and handmade. If you can't get plain noodles right, you have no right being in business.)

When it comes to noodles, Kagawa-Ya knocks it out of the park. My only complaint about the Kitsune Udon was that I ate all the noodles and didn't want to stop! This is udon done right.  
The sweet soybean was a pleasant surprise. I also had the sweet potato tempura, heavenly.  My friends got very excited about something that was essentially spam-fried-rice turned into a waffle cone and stuffed with chicken and other goodies.

The space is open and airy, and always very clean. I love that they have compost, recycling, and landfill bins. The staff is always very courteous to us, and very efficient.
author: Teresa L.

description:
Wasn't quite sure what I was going to get with a fast food Udon place but this place was better than I expected. 

First of all, you can't come to Kagawa-Ya expecting super high restaurant quality Udon. But if you have tempered expectations, I think this place will be perfect for you. The pricing is pretty typical for SF and the portions are about what you would expect for that price. If you start adding all the add-ons, it does get to the pricier end of udon. I got the cold udon dish and it was really refreshing.

Don't come here expecting restaurant quality food. It is a more cafeteria style, fast-food udon but it is good for that experience!
author: Cassie Z.

description:
This place reminds me a lot of a chain I frequented in Japan called Hanamaru Udon where I could reliably get a cheap and delicious bowl of noodles. Kagawa-Ya's selection is significantly smaller (just six options) than Hanamaru's but thankfully one of them is my go to: Kitsune udon.

As in Japan, at Kagawa-Ya you grab a tray, choose an udon and after you're given your bowl you can serve yourself croquettes or pieces of tempura before settling your tab at the end of the counter.

I dig the concept and the offerings but wasn't wowed by my kitsune udon. The tofu was denser than I prefer and the broth was just okay. The tempura bits that topped the dish turned slurry-like quickly which wasn't so pleasant. 

If I were nearby I might stop in again to try the curry udon, but I wouldn't go out of my way to return to Kagawa-Ya Udon.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Similar to Marukame, Kagawa serves the same kind of Sanuki style udon in a modern udon bistro and operate in the same cafeteria style.  They said their udon is made fresh daily.

Take Muni and stop at "Van Ness" station and it's just a couple minutes walk after you exit to the street level.  It's located in the Square / Uber building ground floor.

To get your food, just line up like in a cafeteria, pick up a tray, place your order with the person behind the cook counter, grab your bowl of udon, select your choice of tempura ($1.5 each piece) if you want, then make your way down to the end of the line to the cashier for drinks and pay.  Get your water, tempura sauce, utensils, etc...then find your own table, eat, finish and return the tray to the window where they will collect your dirty dishes.  Pretty much everything is self-serve and you can be in and out fairly quickly if there's no line.

Tried their basic Kitsune Udon with soft boiled egg (onsen style), tempura, spam masubi and onigiri.  Only recommending the udon and tempura and you can skip the spam masubi and onigiri.  Spam was about a 1/4" think and rice almost 1.5" thick, it's completely out of proportion with too much rice.  The onigiri was pretty bland.  

I think I will go back if I feel like a bowl of warm udon soup to warm my soul, I mean tummy in a cold chilly day but otherwise, it's pretty mediocre.
author: Shirley H.

description: This is my go to spot for noodles,  masubi, broth, and specialty drinks in all of sc. They beat out j town and the place on mission across from st lukes. But most def for their broth and noodles which are made fresh multiple times during the day.  I work here in the city as a paramedic and I am always amazed at how fast they make great healthy tasting food.  Even if I only have 3 or 4 mins I can get in and out.  Their prices are more than fair for the amount of food you get.  The place is clean including their bathrooms.  Can't give enough praise!!! The only thing I wish they had was a food truck or cart for when I am posted outside of down town!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
I had the creamy Kabocha, which was noodles in a pumpkin broth with chicken.  
The udon noodles themselves were excellent.
The broth and other condiments were good, but I would describe them more as "interesting" good and not really "wow, I gotta have more" good.

Portion size was average, considering it was a $13 bowl of udon.

I probably won't be rushing back.
author: Lewis C.

description: I got the beef udon. It is good and you can get free tempura if you check in. But I would say it is a little bit pricey compared to some other udon places. But the location is pretty nice and food is decent, really good option if you work nearby.
author: Xu C.

description: Wow. I came here since i love the house made fresh noodles and I'm glad i did!  The place is so clean and spacious. i got the chance to try 4 of the 6 kinds of udon soups. It was SUPER YUMMY ..  the side tempura is unbelievably fresh and the seaweed rice was so neatly packaged and delicious also.  I was so full trying everything and Togo the rest for later. MUST TRY
author: Kate L.

description:
A quick, casual, convenient, and delicious noodle shop! Came here on a Thursday an hour before it closed and there was plenty of seating and no line. 

The menu is pretty simple (6 different udons) and you can choose to add a soft boiled egg for $1.50 or tempura pieces for $1.50/each. 

We tried the Creamy Kabocha with Chicken Udon ($11) and Beef Curry Udon ($13). Though both were very flavorful, I'd have to say my favorite was the Creamy Kabocha. The chicken was very tender and the broth was thick, rich, and flavorful. I enjoyed how the bonito flakes garnish on top moved with the steam! We also decided to try the beef oniguri ($3). The ratio of rice to filling was a little more than I expected, but it was still pretty good. Next time I'll probably opt out of additional small bites since the noodle portions themselves are quite large and filling! 

Apart from the food, the staff here were super friendly! As soon as we entered, we were warmly greeted by the cashier. Overall, I was quite pleased with Kagawa-ya Udon. If you're looking for a quick warm bowl of noodles in the bustling city, this is the place to go!
author: Kris C.

description:
Wow, I had the Creamy Kabocha with Chicken.  With a soft-boiled egg. 
 Oh man oh man oh man.  OK, I'm not an Udon expert, but it was really, really good.  I mean, completely blew me away.  I'm comin' back for this.  But I guess, I should try other things on the menu, b/c if this was so good, maybe the other things are also.

Incredible.  Still kvelling over it, and it was 2hr ago.
author: Chet M.

description:
Definitely worth the drive!  The noodles are made fresh in-house, and you can most definitely taste the difference.  The broth is flavorful... a perfect bowl every time!  Thus far, we've tried the kitsune, niku, curry beef, tomato, cream of clams & leeks, and zha-jiang (the newest recipe!) udons, and we've thoroughly enjoyed each one.  

We forgot to take pictures of our delicious bowls of udon before hungrily diving in.  We'll try to remember next time :)
author: C T.

description: For a place that has udon in its name, Kagawa-Ya did not disappoint. I came here tonight on this very rainy evening craving something warm and soupy and this fit the bill in every single way. I ordered the clam and leek broth with my udon and it was incredible. If you love clam chowder, you're going to love this broth, as its thick and creamy, and shares a lot of the same flavors as your typical bowl of chowder. The broth itself has small bits of clam scattered throughout. I'm not sure if bacon was the best topping to put on the udon (it seemed kind of random), but as somebody who likes bacon, I'm not one to complain :) The udon noodles themselves are cooked to order in front of you so you can expect them to be the perfect texture and consistency. After I picked up my ramen, I selected a few pieces of tempera - the sweet egg, the chicken, and sweet potato. Each piece of tempera was light and crunchy on the outside with no sign of soggy oil. Definitely grab one or two with your udon. A bowl of udon can get pretty expensive if you choose an expensive base and add a lot of tempera ($1.50 per piece), but for the quality, it is well worth the price. I would highly recommend Kagawa-Ya.
author: Austin W.

description:
Delicious tomato udon and awesome selection of tempura.  Friendly service and fast, counter order system.

I enjoy it about once a week.
author: Ryder M.

description:
Food here is served cafeteria style, both for takeout and sit in; everything is self serve apart from any udon dishes (which, you have to order via the kitchen staff). 

Staff are friendly and the restaurant is clean. There are only a few tables so be prepared to either share a table or have your meal as a takeout!

Downsides: although super delicious, the tempura selection on offer and korokke can often be a little cold. This means that you have no idea how long the tempura or korokke have been sitting out for under the heat lamp. 

Each time I've been, the broth for the udon was just luke warm. Thankfully, each time I was super hungry so I ate it pretty quickly! The udon is definitely the star of the restaurant; it has a great chew and thickness and you will not be disappointed. 

Overall, it's a good little restaurant if you want to get your udon fix but I would avoid the tempura and korokke unless you see them coming out fresh! The onigiri are also worth a try if you're feeling greedy :)
author: Simon Y.

description: It was alright. I wish it was better and worth a trip to that area of Market. To be clear I don't live or work near there but I had been wanting some udon, and asked my cousin to meet me there for dinner after work one day. The whole thing was fine but I probably wouldn't go back on purpose. It's a bit too casual in the cafeteria style ness of it. I wouldn't mind the cafeteria style if it was something fantastic. Maybe if I was in the neighborhood, and was craving some udon it would be an good option.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Was pumped to finally try this place out with a friend after seeing it had been under construction since 2016! Overall, it was pretty good for a fast casual place, but the price point just felt a little high for the quality.

It's a fast casual place, so you basically order upfront when you arrive (similar to Chipotle)! At 12:30 on a Friday, there was almost no line - a pleasant surprise! 

I ordered the Creamy Kombucha (#5) for $11 and my friend ordered the Kitsune (#1) for $9.50 with a soft boiled egg ($1.50). While you're ordering, make sure you're getting enough broth - or ask for more if you need!

- Creamy Kombucha: had pretty good flavor - though I found the broth to be lukewarm temperature. Would have preferred if it was warmer and didn't feel like there was that much chicken in the broth, so wasn't feeling I was getting a good deal for the price. I also didn't find there was anything special about the udon noddles themselves. 3/5

- Kitsune: Pretty standard flavorwise for the broth. Again noodles were pretty good, but nothing super out of the ordinary compared to a grocery store. Softboiled egg for $1.50 didn't seem to be worth it to my friend. 3/5

-Tempura: it's sitting under the heat lamps so it's not made to order therefore it's not perfectly crispy! It's pretty good (sweet potato is white instead of typical orange), but I don't think one piece is worth a $1.50. 2.5/5

-Spam Musubi: $3 for a pretty good size. There's a bit too much rice for my taste, and the spam could be fried with a bit more sauce. 3/5
author: Kristie M.

description:
This place is an udon phenomenon cafeteria line kind of place! You line up, choose an udon, pick it up as you go down the line, pick up tempuras with different prices to add, and then pay at the end of the line. Interesting concept. I think it's nice for all the bustling business people working around the downtown SF area to get a quick, filling bite to eat during their lunch break or after work. 
I got the Niku Udon, and it was guud! Very soothing for my stomach. I added a $1 tempura fish cake and thoroughly enjoyed that along with my broth very much. Portions were pretty decent for the price of $14 - $18 for a bowl. That's what you pay in SF for a simple bowl of udon, but hey! It's not the worst you'll see around here. Plus, like I said, the portions were fair. They gave a lot of noodles. At the end of your meal, you clean up after yourself and bring your plates and trays to the kitchen. 
All in all, I liked this place. Wasn't a phenomenal OMG WOWZERS LIKE BEST UDON EVER place. But, I had no complaints!
author: Kim N.

description: My coworker and I decided to order delivery through Uber Eats and try this place out. Thankfully they separated the noodles and broth so it was still hot when it arrived and the noddles weren't soggy. I got the creamy kabocha and chicken and my coworker ordered the Niku. I thought the kabocha broth had a really nice flavor- it's a bit thicker than typical broths bc of the kabocha but it was tasty. My coworker really enjoyed hers too! The noodle portions are pretty generous as well. The only thing missing is vegetables! If you're craving udon, give this place a try. We'll definitely order again to try the other varieties.
author: Stephanie N.

description:
Overview: Kagawa-Ya is a Japanese casual-eatery specializing in udon noodles located under UberHQ between 10th and 11th on Market St. Its dishes are simpler than the equivalently priced Ramen place but they offer a wide variety of tempura pieces a-la-carte for people like me who need more variety of texture and flavor in every meal.

The Establishment: Kagawa-ya's interior is spacious and beautiful with 3-story high ceilings, modern furniture, and a clean, open look. It's almost a cafeteria style system where you start at one end of the kitchen and pick up a tray/bowls and request what you want from the chefs/staff.

The Food: I have both high praise and high criticism for the food here at Kagawa-Ya. Individual aspects of their food are excellent. The udon has a excellent chew, texture and flavor, the broths have just the right balance of sour and savory, the tempura pieces are battered and fried with a good level of crunch without being oily, and the imported drink choices (nectar and teas) are fun to sample. On the flip side, Kagawa-Ya needs to increase the complexity of its meals or increase its value to compete with the well-established ramen places nearby such as Marufuku and Iza. The last time I was here I felt that the beef was overcooked and chewy. 

The Service: This is a order-up-front then bus-it-yourself establishment so I would consider tip being optional here.

Conclusions: Kagawa-Ya is a beautiful, spacious, casual Japanese udon shop with high potential. I suspect that in 2 years, it will either be one of Mid Market's new cornerstones or be out of business.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I was really excited to eat at Kagawa-Ya because I had hopes that it would be similar to or match up to Marukame Udon in Waikiki, Oahu, HI...but man, was I was disappointed. 

To be fair, the concept here is similar to what I was looking for. An fresh udon bar with selections of tempura and yakimomo (pan-fried appetizers). In essence, I think Kagawa-Ya achieved that but San Francisco ruined this one for me. First off, the location is slightly unappealing. While it is in SOMA, close to Uber HQ and Twitter HQ, the neighborhood around it makes me uncomfortable to walk around at night (near Civic Center/Tenderloin). That said, the inside of the restaurant looks clean and modern. The quality and flavor here was mediocre in comparison to what I have had before, lackluster and oversalted at its worst. 

You line up at first to select from their preset menu of udon styles (warm soup, cold udon). After they heat the udon noodles, combine it with broth and toppings, you can take a plate and pick any tempura from a line of selections; ranging from tempura shrimp, carrot, broccoli, curry croquette, spam musubi etc. This style of serving is very similar to Marukame Udon. Overall, the style is similar but the price is 2x as expensive as its counter part in Hawaii. In comparison, the tempura here was poorly made, lukewarm (not nice and piping hot, freshly fried), oily and very heavy to the palate. I really like properly-made Japanese tempura, which seems to be so hard to find in the SF Bay Area.  I guess compared to the average Japanese restaurant, the tempura here is alright. But again, not as fresh tasting or light as the restaurant in Oahu, Hawaii. 

I will say two of their udon soups were more inventive, going for fusion flavors like cream of clam and leek udon, and spicy tomato udon with roasted shiitake. I was quite excited when I saw them and ended up choosing the cream of clam and leek broth. One thing that I definitely surprised me was that the quality of their udon noodles was very underwhelming. It honestly tasted like frozen udon noodles from Japan. It didn't have the nice bouncy al dente texture and freshness from homemade udon, which it actually really quite nice and more alkaline. I don't know where their udon is made or sourced, but they didn't have a noodle chef making it and it also didn't taste homemade to me. 

Now onto the broth. I'm going to be honest, I might be more harsh and critical about broth and taste because I often cook Japanese food at home, eat out at mostly Japanese restaurants, and have stayed in Japan for 2 weeks recently. I expected the broth to taste light, clean, ungreasy and well-balanced. It was the exact opposite of that. The clam and leek broth was oversalted, heavy and did not have a single clam in it!
