It makes me wonder if they used clam juice/clams in a bottle instead of real clams cooked down. The broth did not have depth and was overly heavy. I couldn't finish my dish, which is actually REALLY rare for me.  My husband ordered the classic niku (beef) udon, which was slightly better. However, it too was oversalted and lacked depth and complexity. For the price of about ~$15-18 per bowl of udon, I was pretty disappointed. The spam musubi was pretty standard and nothing to write home about. Because the tempura was lukewarm, fried in a bad batter, it tasted greasy a lack of crispy texture. Tempura, when done well, does a great job at highlighting the freshness of the vegetables, which was not executed well here. 

Overall, it was not a pleasant experience. While seating was plentiful and clean, the environment felt sterile. It reminded me a dormitory cafeteria but without the liveliness and chatter of a college campus. The food was mediocre- broth, noodles AND tempura. I know I am a food snob when it comes to Japanese food, so I understand that my review is low and disagrees with others. That being said, I think even if you do not eat Japanese food much, there are still better options for udon in San Francisco. Maybe they are a bit further, but they'll be a better bang for your wallet and it will taste noticeably better. 

I will try to come back next year to see if there was been improvement.

author: Tokibox 6.

description:
Kagawa-ya sells udon and tempura in sort of a Chipotle type format: you line up for a counter where you tell them which of a few menu items you want and they make it quickly in front of you, then there's tempura vegetables you can grab and canned and bottled drinks on offer as well. 

I stopped by during the lunch rush and there was a line but it moved pretty quickly. The prices we're reasonable and it was possible to grab seats at a table after waiting for just a bit. Seating may be hard to find, though, depending on your luck. 

As for the food, it was very good. The udon was delicious and I really enjoyed some tempura as well. Definitely a good spot to grab a fairly fast lunch, and the location is very nice as well.
author: Jesse C.

description:
This place is great!  I went here for lunch and got the beef curry udon.  I've never had anything like it!  So delicious.  The tempura is perfectly fried, and the spam musubi is also a knockout!  I strongly recommend eating here if you want an udon fix!

Also. Special shout-out to the service!  Everyone was extremely friendly and personable. The cashier was very bubbly and welcoming!  Nice breath of fresh air from a chaotic day in the office!
author: Matt H.

description: Great place for simple Japanese Udon. When you collect stars for 9 bowls of Udon, you get the tenth one free. I ordered the Kitsune which is perfect. You can choose to add your Tempora.
author: Kalin M.

description:
I was not wow-ed. I work across the street and maybe I just had hyped it up in my mind too much.

You get in line and it's like cafeteria line (like Chipotle) where you order your base and as you move down you can add more. I ordered the Creamy Kabocha Udon and it was just okay. I added on one tempura (since it's $1.50 a piece). The taste of the broth is kinda basic to almost bland.

It's quick though and probably comforting on a rainy day but given that I can buy udon soup base and frozen udon noodles from Nijiya and probably recreate this at home, I'll pass on returning.
author: Mimi T.

description: Decided to check this place out before seeing Aladdin.  Delicious Kitsune Udon.  I recommend getting the shrimp and fish cake tempura as well as the creamy potato croquette.  Will be back!
author: Julian C.

description: Here for their soft opening today! They're gonna be officially opened next Wednesday, April 12th. They had reasonable price udon from 9.50-14 and each mini side (tempura) was 1.50 with the option of spam musubi as well as onigiri. Their cold udon already has a broth in it so it's not dipping like you'd imagine. They're currently not open on weekends and once they do open, their hours are 11-7 which is pretty neat since I live at nema and work in the square building! The interior was nice and minimalistic and the place smelled deliciously like my favorite noodles! Excited to have an udon place inside the  building!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Honestly, not the best udon I've had. For a place that specializes in udon, I had high expectations. Pricey for the portion size as well. I was still hungry after my bowl of udon :(

I do like how quickly you get your udon because it's fast food, cafeteria style. I went after work on a Wednesday and there were only two other people in the restaurant.

However, I wouldn't go out of my way to come here again. $19 for a bowl of Niku udon + egg + 1 tempura fish cake?! No thanks. I'll be going elsewhere for my udon cravings.
author: Benita L.

description: This a weird taste of udon, tomato sauce base udon, sauce is too sweet for udon. It tastes more like Italian tomato sauce pasta. Udon is not supposed to be like this, worst udon I have ever had.
author: Ellie Y.

description:
It is finally open! All noodle lovers rejoice!

The moment I caught wind that Kagawa-Ya was open, I set up a little lunch field trip with a dozen coworkers to check it out. The lines was nearly out the door but moves quickly. I was a bit worried about the limited number of seating when I arrived but the steady pace udon being prepped and slurped down seemed to work out perfectly.

I have to admit I was a bit skeptical as I heard others casually comparing Kagaway-Ya to Marukame. Although I think this is a solid contender, the menu options are fewer and of course SF pricing are always going to be bumped up a bit. Then again, well worth the 3 block journey versus a 5 hour flight for an udon fix.

The breakdown:

1) Start by ordering your base bowl, there are 5 options: Kitsune (classic), Cold, Niku (Beef), Curry Beef, a Vegetarian option, and Mushroom Curry (Rice). These base bowls range from $9.50-14

2) Add on as many soft poached eggs or pieces of tempura your heart desires. They are $1.50/each. I was disappointed that the pumpkin tempura were on the small side but the shrimp were big enough to satisfy.

3) Grab a spot and chow down.

I was pretty impressed by the solid umami broth in my kitsune bowl. The bowls might not look very big but they gave me plenty of noodles to feel beyond full. I will definitely be back agin soon.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Hands down the best udon in SF. I love their beef udon and tempura but the real knock-out is the creamy kabocha. I was a little hesitant to try that at first because I knew how easily pumpkin squash broth can go wrong, but it turned out to be very rich and flavorful, not sweet and tangy like I expected. Delicious, satisfying, and fast!
author: Carl W.

description: Great location, clean, friendly, and fast. Came here for the first time the other day. Flavors were great and noodle texture was good as well. I had the Niku and recommend. I also had the shrimp tempura and was ok but could've been a bit lighter on the batter. Many tempura options and spam musubi. The spam musubi seemed like it was mostly rice and wouldn't get again. I would definitely come back again!
author: Emily F.

description:
Very tasty and a good option in the area if you're craving some soul-warming noodle soup on a foggy day! It's cafeteria style so perfect if you're just popping in for a quick bite. 

Now here's the Marukame comparison (and reason why I docked 1 star):
- Only 1 portion size available here. Kagawa-ya's bowl is probably equal to a regular (small) at Marukame. I was satisfied after eating my niku udon with tempura kabocha and egg but not full.
- The udon soup is more expensive than Marukame. Coming in at $13 for a niku udon base where you can get twice the amount of noodles and soup at Marukame for $7
- The niku udon is a delicious clear soup but lacking the traditional Japanese dimensional flavor. Tastes good but is missing "something". 
- Good tempura batter, light and crisp. There is a good variety of tempura to choose from but at Marukame they have many more veggie and meat choices.

This is just me being nit-picky. Seeing as Marukame is 2000 miles away, I will definitely come back to Kagawa-ya.
author: Melissa N.

description: Food was decent. Was Hoping it would be better, but for quick service it was ok. Broth a bit too salty and meat was harder than it should be. Also the tempura was way too overpriced and not good. Tasted like I was eating broccoli in a bland batter with too much oil soaked in. I paid 1.50 for each tempura item on their menu. In total, one bowl plus a runny egg(menu says soft boiled but it's actually poached), plus 2 tempura items and a soda cost me $22. Way too overpriced and the food was just decent.
author: LaSeñorita M.

description:
Loving this new spot!  I've tried the Niku and the Beef Curry Udon.  Both were delicious and as the summer approaches, I can't wait to try the Cold Udon.  YASSSS!  

You really can tell the difference in the quality of their noodles and I love that the service is fast and friendly.  I'll definitely be back!!
author: Lesley Q.

description: For ~$15 per bowl I expected more. There was only one vegetarian option and it wasn't...good. The noodles were kind of cold, the broth tasted a bit like dirt and was under-seasoned. I like umami flavors but this just didn't have any balance to it. Tastes are subjective so you may like it - I personally wouldn't come back here. Definitely wasn't worth it and ended up throwing it out after a couple of bites.
author: Rita R.

description:
I used to work near Uber and would pass the sign that indicated that Kagawa-Ya was opening soon. I've been telling my boyfriend that we needed to go when they opened. So when it finally opened, we went. 

I really liked how the layout was kind of like udon shops that can be found in Japanese subway stations. You get in line, grab a tray, and indicate which kind of udon you want. Then you move your tray along and pick up some tempura pieces before checking out. 

I ordered the kitsune udon and picked up 2 shrimp tempura and 2 croquette. I've always tended to stay away from udon places because I could make almost the same quality udon at home from those semi-instant noodle packets that are sold at Asian markets. The noodles were ok, nothing too special. The tempura and croquettes were crispy, but not hot. 

The prices were a bit pricey, but understandable considering the location. The udon was $9.50 I think, which is ok. But after I added the tempura and croquette, it was an additional $6. 

I will go back if I'm craving udon near Market St. But ultimately, I would rather eat udon at home and go out for ramen.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Don't be fooled by the cafeteria-style line. If this is your first time, I encourage you to pick up that tray and give it a go! You won't be disappointed. The service is quick, clean, and easy. Even my McChickens take longer to come out. But just because it's quick, doesn't mean it's bad...!

[3.5/~$15] Creamy Kabocha w/ Chicken Udon + soft boiled egg was above my expectations considering I thought it said Kombucha at first--I was preparing myself to dive into a bowl of some funky udon SCOBY-juiced, concotion. (I mean, YOLO right?) Luckily, Kabocha is a type of Japanese winter squash. WHEW! Overall it wasn't too bad. This place is no Marugame Monzo (shout outs to Little Tokes), but it'll hold you up for a quick lunch. Wish it was cheaper, but hey, we live in SF, what can we do? Sigh...
author: Brandon T.

description: It was okay. Located approximately at Van Ness and market this option for lunch and dinner was okay. The food/beef udon was good and the restaurant was clean. No fuss, no muss. You go through a line to order, take it to your table, in my case with co-workers. When you are done you bus your own table. No views and no ongoing customer check-in. Not that kind of place. You want noodles and nothing else and you have to get back to work, then it is a good option.
author: Matthew R.

description:
After visiting Tokyo, I thought I'd never be able to enjoy fresh udon again without traveling 5,151 miles. I'm so glad this place opened up! 

I ordered the beef curry udon and instantly fell in love with all the flavors. You can tell that the curry is stewed with a lot of patience and care. The meat was incredibly tender to the point that it fell apart and was everywhere throughout the curry broth. 

Kagawa-ya Udon also has a dope tempura station! I def recommend trying the sweet egg and fish cake. Perfect if you don't want to eat udon, you can always stop by to grab tempura! 

Last but not least, super friendly service! I'll be back to try everything else on the menu!!
author: Steph W.

description:
My love for udon exploded when I had the best curry udon EVER in South Korea. Ever since then, I was on a mission to try curry udon at any restaurant that carried it.

I came with my brother and sister so we were able to try 3 bowls: the beef curry, creamy kabocha, and the cream of clam and leeks.

The curry udon was amazing! Broth wasn't runny and thin but wasn't heavy and salty. The flavor was just right! I love the thick pieces of beef and all the red pickles on top! I was able to finish the entire bowl!

The creamy kabocha was rich and soothing. It felt like a hug when you ate it. I would drink the broth alone because it's THAT good!

The cream of clam was a pleasant surprise! I was thinking "ok, infamous SF clam chowder" but it doesn't have the saltiness of regular clam chowder. It was slightly sweeter and with the bits of bacon, it's definitely a unique one to try! 

It may go without saying but the handmade udon noodle themselves were bomb! Chewy just like they should be.

I'm glad they're open Saturdays now!
author: Anh L.

description:
Really excited to have a good udon place open up in SOMA! I really like the efficiency and reasonable prices. I would say the portions are on the smaller side (I did get take-out). I did pay $13 for the Beef Curry Udon and still felt a bit hungry after, hence the 4/5 stars. However, I do admit that I have a large appetite. I came at around 3pm and there were only a couple diners, but given that Twitter and Dolby are right around the corner, I can imagine this place getting crowded. 

[Food]
There's only five options, so if you're indecisive like me that makes your life a lot easier! I really enjoyed the Beef Curry Udon! The beef was tender and was not overly heavy and the udon noodles were deliciously chewy (I like my noodles al-dente). I'll definitely be back to try the Niku and the Creamy Kabocha Udon. There's also the Cold and Kitsune Udon. 

[Service]
There's a line where you select among the five options. If you want take out they'll put it in a paper bowl for you to take away. Bag is 10 cents. I would say the portion for take away is smaller than eating from the larger bowl. 

[Decor]
Open space with an efficient ordering system. SOMA vibes. 

If you're in SOMA and looking for a no hassle quick and delicious meal, definitely stop by and give this place a try!
author: Alice Z.

description:
My friend recommended this restaurant to me and she did not disappointment me. I had Niku Udon, it was delicious. The beef was tender and the broth had so much flavor. The udon noodles are made in-house, the quality was awesome. I am Asian, so I do appreciate good noodles. My son is a picky eater and he had the beef curry. He loved it. Just recently he asked me to make a trip up to SF for the curry bowl. 

We did add to the order and purchased a spam masubi and shrimp tempura. Both were a great addition to the lunch. Yes, we got more then we needed, but it all looked so good, we could not stop ourselves. 

Really looking forward to my next trip to Kagawa-Ya.
author: Caterina D.

description:
I jumped off the F street Car with my toddler when I saw this place as he loves noodle soups and we were starving. Taking a toddler for soup is not for the faint of heart, but the staff was incredibly gracious and even made recommendations for a toddler-friendly meal. They cooled the broth down for him and even got us a high chair. On top of all this, the udon soups were delicious! I devoured mine and he happily slurped away at his noodles. 

We'll definitely be back and will make stops here part of our adventures downtown!
author: Lisa L.

description: This place is decent, passable udon. If it was cheaper it would get more stars, but the quality is pretty low for almost 20 dollars.
author: Thomas T.

description:
I have been waiting for this udon shop to open for months! Went on the grand opening so the line was long but moved fast. It was really cool to see the chef rolling out the udon right then and there. Chatted with the owner who was at the register and she said it takes 2 days to make the yummy noodles. 

So I've been back twice and both times the noodles, the soup and the accompaniments did not disappoint. The first time I ordered the curry udon. I'm Japanese and love curry, and I have to say, it was legit! The beef in the curry was ridiculously tender and the noodles were cooked perfectly. The veggies in a curry often get overlooked but the big chunks of carrots in there deserve a mention. De-lish.

For my second visit I ordered the Niku udon. Again, the broth was on point and the noodles were great. On my second visit to any restaurant I'm looking for consistency and they definitely were.

Both times I couldn't pass up the tempura. My favorites - shrimp and chikuwa (fish cake). Light and crispy batter, just the way it should be. 

Kagawa-ya now has a permanent spot in my lunch rotation.
author: kumiko e.

description: I tried the Niku Udon. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either, especially for the price. The beef was very chewy and the soup was too sweet.
author: Pat T.

description: Had high hope on this place when I saw on Instagram and yelp. Drive all the way to sf just to try their udon. It was ok......The egg was way too raw I thought it was half boiled and soft inside but is not........also have a lot of MSG I rather to have a bowl of pho lol. Service is fast, restroom and dining area are clean.
author: Mandy C.

description:
Reminded me of my childhood, eating udon cafeteria style in big Japanese supermarkets. it's not supposed to be fancy dining, it's essentially street food but laid out in a cute modern restaurant setting. 

Their tempura is really yummy and light and their udon broth tastes fresh and authentic. 

Smh some people really need to get off their hipster asses critiquing this place for not being gourmet udon. Udon is not gourmet lolol especially when the restaurant is cafeteria style. 

Really delicious, quick, and nostalgic :)
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Wew lads, this may be San Francisco's first authentic professional-grade udon noodle house!

I get regular cravings authentic Japanese noodle dishes, but I'm rarely in the mood to line up for Mensho Tokyo or Hinodeya Ramen. Kagawa-Ya might be my solution from here on -- at 1pm, there was barely a line, and fast casual service meant that I was seated and eating within 5 minutes of entering the establishment.

I recommend getting Kitsune udon (warm dashi broth) with 3 shrimp tempuras. That comes out at $14 for a hearty meal.

The noodles were very dense and chewy and clearly fresh made with a lot of care. It definitely surpasses the quality of frozen sanuki udon (which has more of a light tapioca springiness) and  the noodles at Udon Mugizo (which is often cooked so soggily by their careless staff). The dashi was very rich and satisfying, and the sprinkle of fried tempura batter in the soup definitely brings out a pleasing fragrance.

Keep doing what you're doing, Kagawa-Ya! My only advice is to maybe watch out for your tempura cook (2 shrimps of mine were great, but the eggplant was under-fried and kind of raw). Smooth out kinks and I think this place will last long. Good luck! I will be back.
author: Ken H.

description:
A friend of mine photographed the owners wedding and suggested that I go and try this udon place off market. The service was great and I was even able to meet the owner's. One was working the registrar and the other was head chef. The experience was what I enjoyed most. Being able to watch the entire process from beginning to end right in front of me was very entertaining. While you wait for the udon to be finished, there was an area of tempura with quite the selection. Overall I had a great experience and would definitely recommend this place to anyone likes udon or soup. 

By the way, I ordered the beef curry udon and it was ON POINT!
author: Adam S.

description: Good quality comfort food ruined by not so nice manager. I am soup person and with that said this is the only descent place that serves comfort food. I enjoy their udons every time I go there. Today, I was on an important phone call while ordering and the cashier and manager gave me such an attitude that scared the heck out of me that wouldn't come from a good place.
author: hha a.

description: This place is AMAZING!!! The noodles are chewy and bouncy (if u know what I mean) and the broth is flavorful and not over salted like some places. The meat is tender and the fat melts in your mouth aka the fat is not flubbery. The chives are fresh and have a nice crisp flavor as well. I like how the croquet was crispy on the outside and not over saturated with oil. I'm def going back here (p.s. spam musubi was bomb too)
author: Jade K.

description:
I don't eat carbs regularly, so when I have a cheat meal I have to choose what I want and it better be worth it and Kagawa-Ya Udon is SOOOO worth it. Some of my favorites are the Kitsune Udon, Beef Curry Udon, and Niku Udon, along with their tempura and Spam Masubi.

The udon noodles are so fresh and absolutely amazing, the texture is soft, but has enough bite which is exactly what makes a perfect noodle. The broths are all made from scratch and you can tell, the flavor is amazing and really comes through with every taste. The tempura is fried beautify, light and crispy, and you can't go wrong with the Spam masubi.

If you're in the area, and you want something that is from a legit kitchen, but is still fast and quick definitely check this pace out.
author: Dave W.

description: This is more of a fast food line than a restaurant. The soup was lukewarm and the noodles were overcooked/soggy and didn't have a good texture. It was also on the relatively pricey side. Not worth the price at all.
author: Annie B.

description:
Walked by everyday and been waiting for them to open since last year because I am a food craving person.

A new FRESHLY made Udon in the Soma. This will be my new go-to and pick-up place for lunch since it's really convinenced right next to the office. Only 6 choices on the menu, pretty clear designed, easy to understand and pick, unlike some places where you need to spend few minutes to look for tiny words of the description of the food. Heard that they'll substitute some of the choices in every season/quarter. 

Again, noodles are freshly made and been through stages before it gets to my bowl. So warm and touchy. Get some tempera pieces along with the noodles and I'm full and satisfied for lunch. They always have the Onigiri (the triangle thingy wrapped with seaweed) and spam musubi ready to go. I like to just grab one for snacks :P 

Service is fast, although there's a line. I got my bowl and seated within 5-10 minutes. All you do is to tell the chef which bowl number you want, they will make it for you and you just have to take it on the side, follow the line, and tempera station is self served, keep moving in the line and pay! Staff are nice and helpful. There are tempera/katsu/spicy sauces on the side to adjust your customized taste. I like that they serve the same amount (one serving of the noodles) no matter you dine in or take out. No Cheat Cheat :) 

I normally get the #3 Niku udon and #2 cold udon with shrimp tempera and sweet egg tempera. They are just awesome! Words can't describe the feeling inside me, you just have to try it and you'll know how awesome it is. PS: ask them to add a soft boil egg if you like.

Seats are well organized and clean. Staff will wipe down the table time to time. After you finish eating, just leave the bowl on the side window and the dish washer will take it from you. It's really like a cafeteria setting. 

Around $15-20 a meal depending what you get and my stomach is fully stratified. I will come back for sure just because the food is great and I won't get sick of it.
author: Kalum Z.

description:
Shitty entitled yelp "foodies" who leave reviews irrelevant to the food are the reasons small businesses don't survive in this city.

Do you like convenient locations where you can grab some noodles without waiting in line for 78 minutes? Yay!(which sometimes means you pay a little more because the business has to pay rent?)

Do you like house made noodles with QQ texture? Yay! 

Do you like simplified options that represent a good spectrum of Japanese udon? Yay!

If you don't like any of the above, there is a Cheesecake Factory in union square that will cater to you every whim, include cheap af food, 78 minute wait and 64 page menu. Go there. 

For the rest of the reasonable humans: my favorite broth is kitsune and creamy kabocha. I like to add a shrimp or fish cake tempura and dip in my broth. Add a little Hawaiian sun if I'm getting crazy.

Go, enjoy, be a decent human being.
author: Natasha W.

description:
Finally a place for udon in the Bay Area!!  I'm surrounded by ramen places in the San Mateo region (which I love too), but have grown a little tired of them. 

You can watch the square-cut udon being made fresh in-house, literally the most perfect udon noodles I've ever tasted. 
The place is reminiscent of the popular Marukame Udon in Hawaii, and the line moved quickly. Nice place to grab a quick, quality meal. 

My 4-yr old son loved the #1 classic udon and spam musubi. My husband got the #3 Niku Udon (I had a taste of the amaaazing broth, he drank the whole bowl), and I had the #4 Beef Curry Udon which was savory curry goodness without being too heavy. 

I really loved the tempura. Flaky, light crispy outside without being greasy. I could eat a whole plate of just tempura with the tempura dipping sauce.

Found street parking nearby.

Nice way to warm the body and soul on a windy nippy SF day!  Already craving those noodles........
author: alice a.

description:
If you've ever been to Marukame Udon, imagine a menu with half the selection, 3x the price, and maybe 1.5x the wait, once you order. (If you've ever been to the Waikiki Marukame, you know what I'm talking about.)

Udon doesn't have to be great. But, Kagawa's noodles had no body at all. The soup wasn't bad, but it was a little weak. The kitsune udon had some massive piece of thick, chewy "kitsune" which wasn't really pleasant to eat. I usually like to savor it as I eat, so that was a pretty big disappointment.

I love Japanese noodles, so I really want to have more shops besides ramen in this town. But, I won't be eating here again. If you want to have some good udon, go to mugizo.
author: masa s.

description: Pricey udon, but so is everything in this city. Noodles are good, broth is decent. Solid lunch option, gets the job done but nothing to write home about. Counter service is always stellar, which goes a long way.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Spam Musubi - unfortunately I'm picky with my spam to rice ratio, and I would want my spam crispier, so I'm better off making my own when I have the craving. But good to know where I can get some when craving it/dont' want to make a whole batch! 

Beef curry udon - If you want a gravy type of beef curry, with potatoes and carrots, but just swap out rice for udon, then this is for you. I like marugame beef curry better - that one is more soupy to my taste. 
 
Creamy Kabocha with Chicken Udon- texture of chicken can be hit or miss, but love the broth. This is the thickness consistency I wish the beef curry udon broth was like. 

Spicy Sweet Bean Zhajiang Udon - the best one out of the three thus far to me. Meat is tender, savory flavor, and good amount of veggies. 

I appreciate the unique flavors, quick service, and refreshing variety it brings to the neighborhood. Looking forward to try more flavors! I think the cold udon is next with summer weather approaching! 

People may complain about the price, but noodles made fresh, and portions to me are so huge. If you get the ones with meat, I can't see ordering tempura or musubi in addition anyway.  

Tip - like all the other places around, if your lunch is flexible, go before noon, or after 1pm to avoid the crowds.
author: j w.

description: Place was only OK. I was super excited to try the place since they make their noodles fresh daily, and assemble your bowl in front of you. I tried a place called Marakame Udon in Waikiki, with the same concept, and that place was amazing! I was hoping Kagawa-ya would be just as good, but I was sadly disappointed. This place was pretty expensive as well. A bowl of udon starts off at $11-$15, and you add $1.50 for each tempura topping. My bowl came out to be about $19 because I added a soft boiled egg, broccoli tempura, and shrimp tempura. Would I come again? Probably not.
author: Michelle T.

description: I thought this place was amazing! The service was great and the food was delicious! We ordered 3 bowls to share. The cold, kitsune, and niku. It was all very delicious and the noodles was perfectly cook. My favorite was the cold udon and the niku. The cold udon  was perfect for a warm day in the city. The broth was perfectly seasoned, and the egg, yummmmmmm! The Niku was delicious, I squeeze the left over lemon from the cold udon  and it was perfect! The beef was so tender and flavorful. I only got a zucchini tempura bc I felt it was too much too for two people. I will definitely have to try the others next time. The dipping sauce was on point. I was going to get the spam musubi, but I was too stuffed, the  portions was huge! The prices didn't really bother me, if I'm willing to spend $20+ on ramen at mensho, then I don't think $14 is that bad. I would definitely come back for more.
author: Tia O.

description: Nice and straightforward Ramen house with a good selection of dishes. Flavorful broth and good noodles. My wife tried the pumpkin ramen and that was really good.
author: Daniel N.

description:
I'm leaning towards giving this place 4 stars, but the price bumps it down to a 3.5. The portion is perfect for a nice lunch but I suppose the extra tempura options would be perfect if one were to be hungrier. The udon noodles are made in house and when I was there it looked like a lot of workers were eating there for lunch. 

I guess if you can afford the $12-15 lunch then this would be a good spot to frequent. My experience ordering was extremely efficient and simple. The menu is small with only about 6 different types of soup. The order starts by grabbing a tray, letting the cook know your order, and then scooting over to choose additional tempura munchies for $1.50 a piece. To make the bowls the cook simply puts a portion of noodles in a bowl and ladles in the soup of choice. It took about 2 minutes to get my food and pay. 

Here's what I tried:

Kabocha udon- 3/5. Ever since I went to marugame Monzo in LA I've been dying to find another creamy udon dish that would be up to par. So this dish is really what drew me to try this restaurant anyway. In the end all I have to say is that they're different. Kabocha is a Japanese pumpkin and so the kabocha soup has an earthy, sweet, seaweed taste to it. It was good, but I think I was expecting something else. This dish was $13. 

Beef udon -4/5. What the classic beef udon should taste like. It had thin slivers of beef and some green onions. Not bad! $13 was a bit steep though. 

Curry udon-4.5/5. Definitely my favorite of the three. The udon came with tender pieces of beef stew cubes, carrots, potatoes and some red pickled vegetable. After eating it a while the spice of the curry begins to creep up on you, but it's the perfect amount to leave your nose a little runny. Sometimes curry udon comes with thick kind of gloopy soup and it doesn't really feel like you're eating udon anymore. I really think kagawaya perfectly brings out the Japanese curry flavor I love and balanced it with a really nice broth that is just thick enough to coat the noodles. This dish was also $13.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Needed some soup and happen to walk by this place.  Ordered Beef Curry Udon and the noodles and broth were yummy.  Wish it was a little warmer though.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Bland bland bland.  Noodles were good, broth bad, tempura bad, onigiri awful.  Not worth a visit.

Not sure where these "elite yelpers" ate to give them 4 and 5 star ratings.... But based on the quality of food alone, there's no way that's accurate.
author: Fredrick L.

description:
Great food for the price. My girlfriend and I came here multiple times and have tried the creamy chicken udon, cold udon and zhajiang udon. 

Ambiance:3.5/5

Clean, modern and newly renovated, but market street is never that idyllic of a place to eat, not really the restaurants fault here but above average ambiance for a SF restaurant 

Food: 4/5 
Very tasty udon and flavorings for the price! Zhajiang udon was my fave (reminiscent of my childhood) and surprisingly authentic in flavor

Service: 4/5
Fast and friendly, what else can you ask for. One star off for not allowing phone orders.. why not?? 

Overall solid 4 star restaurant for the area. Awesome for a quick lunch or dinner spot after work. Probably not the best place to bring a date but whatever floats your boat..
author: Pei Lun L.

description: The Niko udon #3 is a great choice. It could use a little more flavor tho. This is my 9th time at this place since it opened and today I was a little disappointed. I walked from work and grabbed $15.00 as I thought my item was $13.00 however I was 19 cents short. I asked can I come back with the 19 cents and I was told no and to come back with the money.  I felt as if I was being treated like I'm begging for free food or as if I didn't have a corporate badge on showing that I work in the area  but anyway the food is okay
author: Michelle X.

description: Walked in right when they opened, so you would expect the soup to be hot, but no! Food is served cafeteria line style, which I don't mind, but the noodles were over cooked and the soup was lukewarm. It's not worth it for the price.
author: Ying Y.

description:
The taste of the udon is good. I had both kitsune and cold udon. The main problem of this place is the price. This place is an insult to Japanese Udon. niku udon in the original Kagawaya is priced around 490 yen. That's $4.3 in today's conversion. The niku udon as of today is priced around $14. That's an insult to anyone who knows that a good udon can't only be good, but it also has to be cheap. I would understand if their portions are larger. I feel full after eating Orenchi ramen where their main ramen is priced around $13. This is not the case for this place, their portions barely makes me full. The tempura prices are alright.

So until they start pricing their niku udon around 8 to 9 dollars and their kitsune around $6 I am not going back. I'm okay if they keep their price but double the portions that is also acceptable. If you're feeling like eating Udon, pack instant kitsune udon from nijiya priced around $1/$2 and skip this place. I guarantee, if they keep their price and portions of today, they'll be out of business in around 6 months.

EDIT:

I'll change the review if they wake up and realize they're not in the ramen business. They're in the udon business.
author: Tomo U.

description: This place is more of a fast-casual dining option for people working around the area. If you are not in the area, I would not recommend going out of your way to try this place. The flavors and udon noodles taste fine, but nothing special. There are much better dining options around SF!
author: Vivian F.

description:
Six words. Spicy Tomato Udon with Roasted Shiitake. So good. Just the right amount of spicy. Good, chewy noodles. Got it without cheese for the vegan option, and didn't miss it, but might try it with cheese sometime. So much flavor and every sip or bite a delight. While I wish they had a soba option, I can only rate what they do have, and what they do have is great.

Note that they change their veggie/vegan option from time to time, but they always have something vegan available. This time they hit it out of the park.
author: Charles B.

description: I have eaten here twice and have thoroughly enjoyed the food, atmosphere and service.  My favorites are the beef curry udon, Zhajiang udon and creamy kabocha all with a soft boiled egg (a must have with the udon) but I have to believe you can not go wrong with any choice from their menu.  My wife likes the simple tastes of the Kitsune as her go to choice with potato croquette tempura and a spam musubi.  The freshness of the noodles and broth can be tasted immediately from the first bite.  I could tell extreme care and attention to detail was given to their ingredients as the food was delicious.  The lines moved quickly as well with more than enough seating in the super clean and spacious dining area.   I am a customer who enjoys value for the price I pay and I will admit the portions are huge with very reasonable prices.  Finally, my wife and I picked up a couple of their custom T-shirts before leaving as we thought the design was unique and looked awesome.  I would highly recommend trying it and would come back if in need of great udon in the City.
author: Victor C.

description:
Nice little spot tucked away in Mid Market serving up freshly made udon and Spam Musubis. Got the Niku Udon with some Tempura and a Musubi. Portion size was perfect and broth was delicious. I can really appreciate the speedyness of service too as I was hungry.

Udon is made fresh daily and the quality of ingredients are top notch. Getting hungry just thinking about it.
author: Derek L.

description:
Their udon is delicious. The place is cafeteria style and has a friendly and laid back atmosphere. Its worth noting it is a bit pricy, due to its location. The cashier was also friendly which was greatly appreciated.

Also nice: There is also tempura you can pick out yourself which is awesome. I got the potato croquette and sweet egg tempura which were really yummy.
author: Art S.

description: Unfriendly! My first time visiting and the server behind the glass was very rude (female).
author: Jessica P.

description: Best udon I've ever had. Please. Can you come and open in London? Combination of luxurious silky udon and broth was sensational. I almost ordered another... instead I'll just tell everyone about it and come back again.
author: Paul C.

description:
$9-$14 for the bowl of udon. Take note that they all come with different toppings also. 
WITH add-ons $1.50 for the tempura items/hard boiled egg or $3 for a spam musibi
I wish it was more customizable considering the only toppings you can choose yourself is the tempura. 

Cold Udon~ It was HOT weather and I wanted to try something different. The broth was light, but nothing too special. I did like that I get the hard-boiled egg included. DEFINITELY add on a tempura item. 
Kabocha Tempura~ It's very creamy, which was too much for my friend and my taste. It did have a strong kabocha flavor.
The udon noodles were good. 

Unfortunately, in my group of 6 and myself just wasn't full after the meal leaving us unsatisfied.

So, YES, I have to compare this to the Marukame Udon in Hawaii (especially since there are Hawaiian drink products sold also at Kagawa-Ya). I LOVE LOVE Marukame all the food is delicious (you see them making the noodles in the storefront) and cheap. Key word is cheap! 
Marukame you can get a bowl of udon, pile on a lot of a variety of toppings that they offer and tempura items, and grab a drink, all for less than $15. A PILE of toppings to get you full. I was spoiled. I just can't go here without thinking of that store.
author: Casie C.

description:
Pretty good for SF. There's not many places that make Udon fresh and this is one of the 3 prominent ones I'm aware of that do make it well. Noodles have a nice chew to it and the broth tastes freshly made with real ingredients.

I've only had the Sanuki udon but do like the broth here. Its light and crisp tasting with just enough flavor for a light meal on a hot day. Will try the kitsune udon next time but the rest aren't as interesting, seems like they're just to round out the menu with more options palatable to the demographic.

One thing they could improve on is not making everything in one big batch. The noodles start tasting old and they lose that springiness near the end of the day. Hot crunchy tempura is a real treat with the sauce but degrades much quicker and starts getting chewier, stale as they turn room temp. It would make a huge difference if they fried to order or at least every hr or two.

It isn't really the place or kind of food that 'must be had' but rather if you already have a taste for it or crave it. The location isn't bad but the restaurant itself feels too much like a cafeteria. If it weren't for places like The Market down the block, it would feel more awkward. It most likely wouldn't do that well if it were an actual hole in the wall with cheaper rent and lower prices though.

Not bad for a quick bite and a little overpriced but the quality is there for when you do want some decent udon.
author: Peel S.

description: Nice to have an udon place to go to amongst all the ramen options around. I like that this place is fast-casual, but the price is where I get caught at. Menu is simple - choose an udon dish. There's only a handful or so. If you want, you can add pieces of tempura to your meal, but each tempura piece is $1.50!! If you eat with your eyes, this can add up easily. Under the heat lamps, they look real inviting. I like the potato and curry potato croquette. But other good ones include a veggie medly patty, pumpkin slice, and zucchini fan. The spam musubi and onigiri are $3 each. Pretty good portion and tasty. I like the kitsune udon best because it's savory and I can add tempura without feeling guilty. The cold udon comes with an egg and has a clean, simple taste. Niku udon has tons of beef. I can eat this one without adding tempura. Creamy kobocha is okay. Tastes buttery, creamy. The tomato udon reminded me of red pasta sauce. Not bad, but not my favorite. Interesting to try. Overall - you line up to order, pay for your order, find a place to sit, which isn't hard because the turnover is pretty high for this casual lunch spot. Clean digs. Bus your own trays.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Update: Their tempura became delicious a little after they opened! It's nice and of light. I now always get at least two prawn tempura with udon. Now they open longer for dinner and even lunch on Saturdays. Go Kagawa-ya!
author: Akiko O.

description: The kabocha ramen is truly awesome. It's worth getting in the car and making the trip. Together with the 'out of this world' noodles this is a firm favourite of our team. Absolutely love the place.
author: BeAkira L.

description:
Cold Ramen 
Flavor - 2.5 out of 5, average, nothing spectacular 
Udon - 3 out of 5, cooked well 
Portion - 1 out of 5, for 11 dollars, not worth it for the size 

Tempura variety - 2 out of 5, don't get the deep fried sweet egg or fish cake

Spam musubi - 1 out of 5, lacking flavor and spam 

Katsu sauce was horrendous and super sour 


What we ordered - cold udon and traditional udon (tofu skin was extremely sweet), regular and curry potato, 3 shrimp tempura, spam musubi, tempura sweet egg, tempura fish cake and 2 drinks  for 45 dollars
author: Vince L.

description:
Don't expect good Sanuki udon noodles at this place.

I had cold udon noodles at this place. It is the best item for quality test on udon noodles. Honestly speaking, it was below the bar. I expected it should be Sanuki udon noodles since the place name is "Kagawa" (Sanuki is the old name of Kagawa). Maybe my expectation was too high.

In the other day, I tried hot kitsune udon. The broth is good. But the noodles are not good for hot broth as well.
author: Satoshi N.

description:
I have been hearing about this spot for months and am so happy they are now open!!!

This was the most delicious Udon I have ever had in my life, and that is no lie!  I had the Beef  Curry Udon and the texture was so good I couldn't believe what I was eating.  The portions were generous, the broth was Hot and the service was excellent!  I can barely button my pants' but can't stop thinking about when I am going to go back and if what I will have next time!!!

I love noodles, I really love Udon Noodles and I have finally found the perfect spot!
author: Mac S.

description:
I came here with 3 coworkers around 11:45 am Tuesday morning, and there were only 4 people eating inside, plenty of space! Most of the tables are right next to each other so you'll have to be comfortable potentially bumping elbows with strangers.

The restaurant is cafeteria style: you grab a tray, tell them your order, and watch them blanch the noodles, scoop up the broth of your choice, and hand you your bowl. 

Next you slide your tray by the tempura selection. They provide small plates so there's no need to soak them on your soup. They have curry potato and creamy potato coquettes, as well as shrimp, squash, sweet egg, sweet potato, zucchini, and fish cake tempura, all for $1.50 each. 

If you want something small, you can get spam musubi or beef niku onigiri for $3 each.

They have a small side table with cold water, hot sauce, and tempura sauce. The tempura sauce was good, not watered down at all. 

Only complaint: They need better soup spoons. It was very hard to get the yumminess at the bottom.

I had their beef curry udon today. Very flavorful. I prefer my curry spicy so I had to shake some pepper into it, also available at the side table. Don't bother comparing it to Muraccis because nothing can compare. But as a near-by lunch option with yummy food, I will definitely be back!
author: Lilimae S.

description: I had no idea what the food was going to be like, but It was dinner time and I missed lunch so I went for it bc it was the closest eating establishment to me. Usually, in moments of hunger desperation, I make terrible restaurant choices because I'm so hungry I could eat a kangaroo. So I usually end up eating some unidentifiable food that quite possibly contains... well, kangaroo. But the experience at Kagawa-Ya miraculously broke my personal Hunger Games losing streak, offering the exact experience I needed (quick serve-at-the-counter & easy to go), and the udon soup was hearty, satisfying, & delicious. The soup was more solid food than broth, so while it seemed pricey, it was filling enough to split into two meals. I had the Beef Curry (which is nothing like Indian Curry, btw) & it was almost exactly like my grandmothers beef stew (which I've missed almost as much as I have her), but with udon noodles. It's my new go-to when in that part of the city. The kind of food you crave and can't wait to get next time. AND... while this may disappoint some, I was relieved when I realized the soup did not contain even a trace of any kind of marsupial.
author: Jill S.

description: Haven't come across any places specializing in udon in the area; I was so excited to finally try Kagawa-Ya! I got the Creamy Kabocha with Chicken Udon, which was a wonderful mix of rich broth, tender chicken, and of course, fresh and chewy udon! The place offers classics such as niku and kitsune, as well as their own creations like the tomato and shiitake; it was really difficult to settle on one bowl out of so many tantalizing options. An assortment of tempura was available at $1.50 per piece. I got the vegetable kakiage and the potato curry croquette, two of my favorite appetizers, and they did not disappoint. There are also interesting tempura like the fish cake and the sweet egg, which I wanted to try as well. After my meal, I got the spam musubi and the beef onigiri to-go; portions for both were very hearty, and I especially liked how the flavors of the nori and green onion worked their way into the onigiri. As expected from the location, prices here are slightly on the higher end, but the creativity of the menu, as well as the quality and care the people here put into their food, more than make up for it. I'm looking forward to visiting again and trying more of their delicious udon and tempura!
author: Yen Ting L.

description: Overhyped! Noodles are okay, but I'd recommend checking the tempura sauce to make sure it's HOT before you order any tempura because the tempuras aren't made to order nor will they have hot tempura sauces/make new sauce at 5:30pm knowing the store closes in 1.5 hrs (7pm).
author: Eudora Z.

description: Pretty good but a bit pricey but it's expected for the area.  We got the number 1  and tempura and we really liked it. Wish the broth and tempura were little bit more warmer but besides that it was good.
author: Samantha N.

description: Not a bad place for a quick dinner. Clean, well lit space. Food was filling and affordable. The noodles were a bit mushy and my chicken was on the dry side but flavors were decent and I liked the tempura.
author: Jen K.

description: The food is delicious and the portions are plentiful. I gave four stars instead of five because it is a bit pricey. The cost will stop me from returning on a regular basis.
author: Geno M.

description: Great udon! All fantastic choices made fresh by husband and wife duo. Get there early so you can beat the lines. Tempura is crisp and yummy to add on the side of your udon. A must try and continue to go back kind of place. Location is perfect. Great job Katherine and Sean!!!
author: Daniel R.

description: I am getting over a cold and wanted something other than the usual chicken soup, pho, etc. (plus been there done that didn't help)  I ended up getting the niku udon, which hit the spot. The noodles have the perfect texture, not surprising since they make it fresh in house. The beef slices had the tiniest amount of fat to make it tasty, but not so much that I'm having to tear off visible pieces of fat. The broth is soothing, flavorful, clean (not greasy), and just perfect for a person fighting a cold on a chilly SF summer day.
author: Rache C.

description: The atmosphere is friendly and welcoming, and the customer service was nice. The noodles were very fresh. I think next time I would get my noodles warm, instead of cold, though. Overall, average price for food in SF and a creative menu.
author: Nicole H.

description: Very tasty food- noodles and tempura especially. Clearly priced for the tech crowd who don't bat an eye at spending $20 for lunch. Too rich for my blood- no matter how good everything tastes.
author: Kelley M.

description:
Seriously, I have experienced better. 

This place is located right beside our office and I think they've been open for about a month now. It's conveniently located to some of the biggest company and offices around downtown. The place is just ok since it's nicely decorated, unlike some other ramen house I've been to. I look plain and dull really. Nothing that stands out really. I think came in like a week after their opening and I was just curious if the place was any good. There was just a few chair that just looks out of place. There were only a few chairs out and seems very disorganized but you can easily see where the counter where to place the order. The menu was actually nice and clear that even without my glasses I saw it.

Now, the only issue was the quality of the food for the amount I paid. When I came in, I asked the chef, what can he suggest for me. I was thinking about getting the Niku udon but since it's something new for me, I went to trust the chef suggestion. I had it go since there was not much chair. Like I said, it's just a huge space with a kitchen/counter. The suggested the curry udon as it's one of the best selling they noodles, which I find weird but ok, might as well. I would've thought he'll suggest a classic udon with miso soup. I got my order really fast and the lady handed me over the plastic. I took a peek of the bag since I thought for the amount that I just paid, I will be getting a lot more. I was so tempted to ask the lady if this is the $15 Beef Curry Udon I ordered. I swear, I thought there was more like. Yes, it was the typical take-out with a small container for my food. I was so disappointed coz I just paid with $15.  I went back to our office and I was hoping that the tastes weren't that bad. There was nothing but noodle and curry. There was some few pieces of meat and definitely not more than 4 small pieces. Not even that good either.

For that price and quality, seriously, I have experienced better.
author: Marvic R.

description: Service is great and fast but it's overpriced. Don't get me wrong, the udon i've had there the last few times have been delicious but $14 for beef udon is too much for the size you get. You can get a bigger bowl in Japantown for the same price, not like the "to-go" size bowl here at Kagawa. If it were more in $11-12 range that would make me come back more often for lunch on a regular basis cuz I love udon.
author: victoria y.

description:
Been here 3 times, got food poisoning the 3rd time :( I enjoyed the food when it stayed down, don't think I'll ever be coming back :(

Changing review: Just wanted to update this to say that the owner reached out to me which was sweet and I didn't expect that. I have to add that the restaurant does present as clean, and maybe I just happened to get unlucky. Maybe one day I'll come back, for now I just don't have the stomach for udon or spam musubi...
author: Ceanne H.

description: Oh man, this place has the best udon. Try everything at least once and order your favorites over and over again. I use their delivery service through trycaviar when I can't leave work.
author: Rachman C.

description: Love the interior of this place! It's modern and super clean. I had the beef curry udon with tempera shrimp and squash and spam matsubi. I loved the beef curry udon. The broth was creamy with chunks of velvety beef. Ordering and service was extremely efficient and friendly. Can't wait to come back to try the other items on the menu!
author: Mel T.

description: I think their soup and noodle are getting better!! I love it. Actually I go there at lease 3 times a month:))
author: Iguanatte S.

description: I was hoping that this place would be like the Marukame Udon in Oahu. San Francisco is well-overdue for a good old cafeteria style Japanese noodle place offering variety of tempura and rice balls to go with noodle soup.  The place fell short in a few aspects that are fundamental for a good casual Japanese noodle place.  First of all, their broth lacked umami.  Second, it is overpriced for this type of eatery.  Yes, this place is located in a building that houses Uber in now trendy and pricey Mid Market area.  However, there is no excuse for a cafeteria style place to charge $10 + dollar (the most basic option starts with $9.50 plus tax) for a mediocre tasting bowl of soup.  If you are looking to try udon noodle soup, I recommend Udon Mugizo in Japantown.
author: Ryoko M.

description: This place conveniently located near transportation. The service was quick. When I went there virtually no line and there were tables available. I had the curry beef Udon. The flavor was great. The amount of meat provide was plentiful. For me this was four stars. I also order shrimp tempura and the croquette. They both were cold to luke warm and this was at noon. Serving cold food is not acceptable two stars (if warmer it would have been four). Portion size is small but for me this wasn't problem, in terms of being full. The reason I am not a fan is the cost. I understand SF is expensive, so the price is not surprising, However, I  wouldn't add it to my go to place for lunch. For others, I thinks it's a great place for  lunch if you want a quick bite to eat and don't mind spending $15 for lunch.
author: Yaya H.

description: Yum. They sure have improved this place since they first opened. The portions are much larger, and the tempura was fresher. Very enjoyable udon.
author: Bruce M.

description: I love the food and the service. I lived in Japan and this is this restaurant closely resembles the quality and the experience of some Tokyo restaurants.
author: Alex T.

description: loved the noodles. Very tasty, one of the best I've ever had. Kind of pricy, but you get a good portion.
author: Ramin A.

description: I am so glad Kagawa is in San Francisco! The udon there is amazing and reminds me of Marukame Udon in Honolulu. I had the curry udon, and the curry was exactly what I needed it to be. There were good size chunks of meat and the curry was the correct spicy level. The only mistake I made was thinking the eggplant tempura was sweet potato, so I definitely need to come back to grab the correct thing next time.
author: Belle Y.

description: Good food. Waiting was not long. I got a curry udon bowl with 2 pieces of tempura. It was about $17 before tax and tips. I found too expensive for the amount of food. Right after I finished my food, I went back to the office and devoured a bag of snacks. You're leave this place hungry if you an average size guy.
author: Ken D.

description: This place looked like the food would be very good, and since me and my friend were craving some form of noodles, we went to this udon place. The first thing we noticed was the style of how you order- its different from most places, in that it is reminiscent of a school cafeteria. You grab a tray, place your order, and move down a line to get your bowl and then choosing tempura if wanted. Then you pay at the end. I don't think tips are required. I got the creamy kabocha chicken udon, while my friend got the kitsune. The chicken one was pretty good, with a nice portion: it doesnt leave you starving, but you don't get too full either. The kitsune was not as creamy as the chicken udon, obviously, but was equally as good with a giant fish cake and nice salty soup. The kabocha's soup was a little bland, and was not exactly salty. However, everything else balanced out to create a harmony. If you are looking for something not as salty, I would recommend the kabocha, and for the ones craving something saltier, the kitsune.
author: Melody Z.

description: I had the pleasure to eat at this restaurant. I tried three dishes already and will definitely come back.  The price is reasonable, food taste Really good, amazing decoration and all clean and nice people.. San Francisco deserved places like this.. I'll come back for sure.
author: Luis V.

description: I tried the beef curry udon and it was very good. Just hit the spot on a cold SF day! I would recommend it.
author: Michael H.

description: Kagawa Ya my "go to" spot for Udon in town. Nothing compares to their Beef Curry Udon bowl. Check out the Kagawa Ya Udon team for "oodles of noodles"!
author: Christopher T.

description: I frequently work at City Hall and found this place about 2 blocks away. Love that the menu is super easy and simple (straight to the point). I have now visted 2X and must say it's amazing! I recently had the Beef Curry Udon and as I was checking out they surprised me with Spam Musubi which was a perfect combo. Fast service for lunch which is highly accommodating.
author: Oscar U.

description: Awesome noodles! Chewy and firm at the same time, the perfect bite. Very clean space and smiley service. A very welcome addition to the mid-market restaurants. I already wanna come back and try all of the bowls! I live in this neighborhood, so my wish is that they stay open during the weekends. The Market (Twitter HQ) is very busy on Saturdays and Sundays, they should tap into that market.
author: Jonsey B.

description: The food is very good quality, but I give it 3/5 stars because there aren't many options, and it's pretty expensive-- $18 for beef udon, then $1.75 for each piece of tempura.. but I know it's in the city so I guess that's what you could expect to pay, even for a bowl of noodle soup.
author: Jannet H.

description: This place is clean and inviting. Very cool monitors for the menu. We were a party of 4 and tried 4 different bowls of udon and just about every side of tempura and wrapped appetizers. My favorite was the curry udon. It was super flavorful and not salty. The others liked the beef broth and original. There is no substitutions but you don't need to, the bowls are delicious just the way they are. I brought my 3 yr old in and she loved it which is saying a lot since kids are picky. Just found out they deliver too. Yay!
author: kelly y.

description: Fresh noodles, great broths and toppings. Portions are just right and the price is reasonable. One of my favorite lunch spots on Market.
author: Eric W.

description: I absolutely LOVED the food!  Everything was made fresh onsite, and before your very eyes!  The noodles are incredible and loved the Kabocha Udon!!!!!  The ambiance is also light and bright and it was a nice place to be in as well.
author: Daniel F.

description: I want to like it more, but it's just okay.  I got the Kitsune udon ($9.50) and added a piece of fishcake tempura ($1.50 per).  And I agree that it's a little pricey, especially for the non-meat (what is fish considered?) version.  Flavor is okay.  It had a lot of oil, and I felt a little greasy (and yeet hay) after. Tempura wasn't the crispest, but it's also been sitting out for a while.  The portion sizes worked for me. I'd probably just add more tempura pieces on hungrier visits.  I'm not opposed to going again, but I'm also not rushing back.
author: Glo T.

description: Way too expensive even for SF for what you get- total was $16 for a bowl of measly , greasy fatty bits of beef with no veggies and $1.50 per tempura piece-not going back there ever again.
author: Jamie M.

description: Amazing spam musubi and onigiri ! Beautiful and warm space and very friendly employees :)
author: A V.
